 Diagnosis
 Scheuermann's Disease

 Developmental disorder causing increased kyphosis (rounded back) in adolescents. Affects 4-8% of the
 population. Early detection is important for best outcome.

 Read more
 

 
 Diagnosis
 Flat Back (Hypokyphosis)

 Too little curve in the thoracic spine can surprisingly cause more issues than rounded back.
 Especially affects people with rigid posture and can cause compensatory problems.

 Diagnosis
 Costochondritis

 Inflammation of the cartilage between ribs and breastbone. Often gives frightening chest pain that
 can be mistaken for heart disease. Common and benign condition.

 Diagnosis
 Kyphosis (Rounded Back)

 Increased curvature in the thoracic spine - from functional postural failure to structural changes.
 Important to distinguish between types for correct treatment.

Behandling

 

 Behandlingen av kalkskulder avhenger av symptomintensitet og fase. Fordi tilstanden er selvbegrensende, er målsetningen å lindre symptomer mens kroppen selv tar seg av kalken.

 Konservativ behandling (førstevalg)

 
 Hva kan kiropraktoren/fysioterapeuten gjøre?

 
 Manuell behandling: Mobilisering av skulder og brysthvirvelsåylen

 Bløtvevsbehandling: Arbeid med stram muskulatur rundt skulderen

 Øvelsesveiledning: Tilpassede Øvelser for å opprettholde bevegelighet og styrke

 Ergonomisk rådgivning: Tilpasning av arbeidsoppgaver i akutt fase. Se ergonomi og skulderplager

 
 

 Ståtbølgeterapi (ESWT)

 ESWT (Extracorporeal Shock Wave Therapy) har Level I-evidens for behandling av kalkskulder. Ståtbølger sendes mot kalkavleiringen for å stimulere resorpsjon og lindre smerte.

 
 KALK-studien (BMJ 2023)

 En norsk studie (KALK-studien) sammenlignet ESWT med placebo. Interessant nok viste studien ingen signifikant forskjell mellom gruppene ved 4 og 12 måneder. Dette kan skyldes at pasienter med kortere symptomvarighet ble inkludert - der tilstanden kanskje ville gått over uansett.

 Andre studier med lengre symptomvarighet har vist bedre effekt av ESWT. Behandlingen kan våre mest nyttig for pasienter med langvarige plager som ikke viser tegn til spontan bedring.

 

 Andre behandlingsalternativer

 
 Ultralydveiledet barbotage (nåling)

 En nål føres inn i kalkavleiringen under ultralydveiledning. Kalkslam aspireres og skylles ut. Kan våre effektivt, særlig i r...

Describe causes and risk factors for Kyphosis and Poor Posture.

Causes and Risk Factors

 There are two main types: Functional (postural) hyperkyphosis is caused by muscular
 imbalances and poor habits - the curve straightens when you lie flat or consciously straighten up.
 Structural hyperkyphosis (like Scheuermann's
 disease ) involves actual changes in the vertebrae and is rigid.

 From most common to least common
 1. Prolonged Sitting (Most Common)

 A Thai study from 2022 showed that office workers who sit more than 4 hours daily have a 2.5
 times higher risk of musculoskeletal problems compared to those who sit less (Jalayondeja et
 al., BMC Public Health 2022). EU-OSHA recommends maximum 2 hours of continuous sitting before taking a
 break.

 2. Smartphone Use ("Tech Neck")

 When you look down at your phone, your head bends forward and dramatically increases the load on your
 neck. Hansraj (2014) calculated that for every 15 degrees the head bends, the perceived head weight
 increases from about 5 kg to 12 kg - and at 60 degrees of flexion, a full 27 kg . A 2023
 study showed that two-handed smartphone use acutely increased thoracic curves by about 12 degrees.

 3. Weak Back Muscles

 Katzman et al. (2017) found in the SHEAF study that people with hyperkyphosis had 19% reduced strength in
 the back extensor muscles compared to the control group. Weak muscles make it harder to maintain good
 posture over time.

 4. Age

 Kyphosis angle naturally increases by about 3 degrees per decade after age 40. Women show faster
 progression than men, especially after menopause (Fon et al., 1980). Among adults over 60, 20-40% have
 hyperkyphosis (Katzman et al., 2010).

 5. Structural Causes (Least Common)

 Scheuermann's disease affects 0.4-8% of the population and causes
 rigid, structural kyphosis with wedge-shaped vertebrae. Osteoporosis with
 compression fractures is another structural cause - each fracture increases kyphosis by an average of 3.8
 degrees (Kado et al., 2013).

Describe symptoms and signs of Hallux Valgus (Bunion).

Symptoms and Characteristics

 

 Many with hallux valgus have no symptoms - it is only when pain or functional problems arise that
 treatment becomes relevant.

 
 Pain over the joint: Typically worst when wearing shoes, better barefoot

 Redness and swelling: Over the protruding joint, especially with friction from shoes
 

 Stiffness in the big toe: Gradually reduced mobility in the MTP joint. With
 significant stiffness, also consider hallux rigidus

 Metatarsalgia: Pain under the forefoot due to
 altered loading pattern

 Hammer toes: Secondary deformity of 2nd-5th toes because the big toe presses against
 them

 Gait changes: Altered foot mechanics during walking

 

 
 Progressive Condition

 Without intervention, hallux valgus tends to gradually worsen. Studies show the angle increases by
 about 1-2 degrees per year in untreated cases. Early intervention with conservative measures can slow or
 stop progression.

Skriv subjektiv del av SOAP-notat for en pasient med Vestibularisnevritt.

Vestibularisnevritt er en plutselig funksjonssvikt i balansenerven på en side av hodet. Balansenerven sender kontinuerlige signaler fra det indre Øret til hjernen om hodets posisjon og bevegelser. Når denne nerven plutselig slutter å fungere, oppstar en dramatisk ubalanse mellom signalene fra de to orene.

 Hjernen tolker denne forskjellen som intens rotasjon - selv om du ligger helt stille. Resultatet er kraftig vertigo (følelsen av at rommet spinner), kvalme og problemer med å holde balansen.

Skriv behandlingsplan for Horisontal Kanal BPPV.

Behandling

 

 Hva kan kiropraktoren gjøre?

Differential diagnoses for POTS and Orthostatic Dizziness?

Viral Infection (most common)

 About 50% of POTS cases start after a viral infection - especially mononucleosis (glandular fever), influenza and COVID-19. Among patients with long COVID, 2-14% report POTS symptoms.

Physical Trauma

 Whiplash injuries , concussion and other trauma to head and neck are known triggers. There is a documented connection between neck injuries and POTS development.

Associated Conditions

 POTS often occurs together with other conditions: Hypermobile Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (25% of POTS patients), mast cell activation syndrome (MCAS), migraine (40%), irritable bowel (30%), and ME/CFS (21%).

Describe diagnosis for Muscles and Trigger Points That Cause Headache.

Diagnosis

 Headache from muscular causes is diagnosed primarily through clinical examination . Imaging such as MRI or CT is rarely necessary for typical tension headache and often shows findings like wear or degeneration that do not explain the symptoms.

 The Examination Includes
 Palpation of neck and facial muscles to locate trigger points

 Assessment of whether pressure on the trigger point reproduces the patient's known headache

 Posture assessment including forward head position

 Neurological screening to rule out serious causes

 Craniovertebral mobility and neck joint function

 ICHD-3 Classification of Tension Headache
 Infrequent episodic: Less than 1 day/month

 Frequent episodic: 1-14 days/month

 Chronic: 15 days or more/month for over 3 months

Assess red flags: 43-year-old male with mechanical thoracic back pain after skydiving 2 days ago. Pain between shoulder blades. Reproducible with rotation and palpation. Normal breathing, normal SpO2. No neurological symptoms.

URGENCY: MONITOR

No acute red flags, but NOTE: skydiving = significant axial loading.

Clinical reasoning:
- Pain is reproducible = mechanical component confirmed
- Normal breathing and SpO2 = no pneumothorax/pulmonary pathology
- No neurological symptoms = no cord compression
- BUT: skydiving = significant axial loading at landing
- Compression fracture can have subtle initial presentation

Precaution:
- Palpate each segment for focal percussion tenderness (vs. diffuse muscular soreness)
- If ANY focal tenderness over spinous process → X-ray

ACTION: Gentle treatment. Thoracic spine X-ray recommended due to trauma mechanism. Reassess in 3-5 days.

What causes Neck Pain During Pregnancy - Causes and Safe Treatment?

Causes of neck pain in pregnant women

 

 Neck pain during pregnancy is caused by a combination of factors:

 
 Hormonal changes (affects all pregnant women)

 During pregnancy, the body produces the hormone relaxin, which loosens ligaments and connective tissue to prepare the body for childbirth. Relaxin levels are highest in the first trimester, but the hormone remains in the body throughout pregnancy and for several months after delivery.

 

 
 Postural changes and center of gravity shift

 As the belly grows, the body's center of gravity shifts forward. To compensate, many pregnant women lean backward, leading to increased curvature in the lower back. This postural change propagates up the spine and affects the neck.

 

 
 Weight gain and breast enlargement

 The natural weight gain during pregnancy - typically 10-16 kilograms - puts extra strain on all weight-bearing joints. Breasts can increase significantly in size, pulling shoulders forward and creating tension in the upper back and neck.

 

 
 Sleep disturbances

 Good sleep becomes more difficult as pregnancy progresses. Many pregnant women struggle to find a comfortable sleeping position, need to get up multiple times during the night, and generally have restless sleep. Poor sleeping positions can lead to stiff and painful neck in the morning.

Describe Clicking That Disappears - Should You Worry? for Clicking, Locking and Joint Problems in the Jaw.

Clicking That Disappears - Should You Worry?

 

 Many become worried when clicking suddenly stops. Here's what it can mean:

 Harmless Causes

 
 The joint has adapted and the disc glides better

 Less stress (stress reduction, better posture)

 Natural variation

 

 Causes That Require Attention

 
 Sudden stop + limited opening = possible transition to locking

 Sudden stop + increased pain = inflammation in the joint

 

 
 Rule

 If clicking disappears AND you can open normally without pain, it's probably good. If clicking disappears AND you have problems, seek help.

Diagnostikk

 Diagnosen stilles primært gjennom klinisk undersøkelse. Sykehistorien er ofte avslærende: smerter som varierer med BH-bruk, synlige stropp-furer, og bedring i helger eller ferier når pasienten bruker BH mindre.

 Differensialdiagnoser som må vurderes

 Tilstand 
 Kjennetegn 
 Skiller seg ved 

 Cervikal radikulopati 
 Typisk ensidig, følger dermatom 
 Positiv Spurlings test, refleksforandringer 

 Thoracic outlet syndrom / T4-syndrom 
 Lignende symptomer, ofte ensidig 
 Ingen synlige stropp-furer, vaskulære symptomer 

 Rotatorcuff-problemer 
 Smertebue, svakhet ved visse bevegelser 
 Positive impingement-tester, smerter ved aktive bevegelser 

 Om bildediagnostikk

 MR og røntgen er sjelden nødvendig for BH-stropp-syndrom. Disse undersøkelsene viser ofte "normalfunn" som slitasjeforandringer som ikke forklarer smertene. Den kliniske undersøkelsen - med fokus på stropp-furer, symptommønster og respons på BH-fjerning - er viktigere enn bilder.

Behandling

 

 Hva kan kiropraktoren gjøre?

 Bakre kanal BPPV behandles med reposisjonsmanØvrer som forflytter de løse krystallene ut av buegangen og tilbake til utriculus. Den mest brukte og best dokumenterte metoden er Epley-manåveren.

 
 Effekt og evidens

 
 75-95% av pasientene blir symptomfrie etter en eller flere behandlinger (Cochrane Review, 2014)

 32-90% opplever bedring etter første behandling

 Suksessraten Øker til nesten 100% etter 3-4 behandlinger

 Hva kan du gjøre selv?

 Unngå å legge deg flatt de første timene etter behandling

 Sov gjerne med hodet litt hevet første natten

 Unngå plutselige hodebevegelser de første dagene

Beskriv Behandlingsforløp i kontekst av Kostokondritt og Brystsmerter.

Unngå aktiviteter som forverrer smerten - gi brusken tid til å roe seg

 Varme kan lindre - varmepute eller varm dusj over det Ømme området

 Forsiktig tøyning av brystmuskulaturen, for eksempel i en dØrÅpning

 NSAIDs (ibuprofen, naproxen) kan hjelpe på kort sikt - snakk med lege/apotek

 PusteØvelser - rolig diafragmatisk pust kan redusere spenning i brystkassen

 
 

 Behandlingsforløp

 Basert på tilgjengelig litteratur kan du forvente:

 
 
 Akutt kostokondritt (<6 uker): De fleste opplever betydelig bedring innen 2-4 behandlinger når brystryggen inkluderes i behandlingen.

 Kronisk kostokondritt (>12 uker): Studien av Zaruba & Wilson (2017) viste at selv langvarige tilfeller (gjennomsnitt 6+ måneder) responderte godt på 4-5 behandlinger over 3-4 uker.

 Konservativ behandling: En observasjonsstudie (Disla et al., 1994) viste at 91% opplevde symptomlindring innen 3 uker med hvile og betennelsesdempende medisiner.
You are a medical safety advisor for chiropractic. Provide differential diagnosis based on symptoms and clinical findings. Always prioritize patient safety.
Differential diagnoses for Ankylosing Spondylitis?

HLA-B27

 90-95% positive 

 A gene found in most people with ankylosing spondylitis. However: 8% of the general population also
 has this gene without developing the disease. A positive test is supportive but not diagnostic alone.

Inflammatory markers

 CRP and ESR (erythrocyte sedimentation rate) may be elevated but are normal in up to 40% of patients.
 Normal CRP does not rule out ankylosing spondylitis.

Pelvic X-ray

 Shows sacroiliitis (changes in the SI joints). Required for classic AS diagnosis according to New
 York criteria. May be normal early in the disease course.

MRI

 Important for early diagnosis 

 Can show active inflammation (bone marrow edema) in SI joints and spine before X-ray changes occur.
 Crucial for diagnosing non-radiographic axial spondyloarthritis.

 Hormonelle forandringer:

 
 Relaxin løsner opp leddbénd og ledd å gir mindre stabilitet

 Musklene må jobbe hardere for å kompensere

 
 Mekaniske forandringer:

 
 Tyngdepunktet forskyves fremover

 Økt svai i korsryggen (hyperlordose)

 Typer smerter under graviditet

 
 Lumbal smerte: Sentralt i korsryggen, ligner vanlige korsryggsmerter

 Kiropraktorbehandling er trygt under graviditet:

 
 Tilpasset leddbehandling

 Bløtvevsbehandling

 Øvelser og ergonomiske rød

Describe What is a stress fracture? for Stress Fracture in the Foot.

What is a stress fracture?

 

 Bone is living tissue that is constantly being broken down and rebuilt. When the load is greater than the
 bone's capacity to repair itself, a "stress reaction" - a precursor to fracture - first occurs. If loading
 continues, a stress fracture develops. This differs from acute injuries like ankle sprains.

 
 
 2-5%
 of all sports injuries
 

 
 95%
 in lower extremities
 

 
 2-3x
 more common in women
 

 
 6-8 weeks
 typical healing time
 

 

 Most Common Locations in the Foot

 
 
 
 Location
 Proportion
 Risk Level
 Healing
 
 
 
 
 2nd-3rd metatarsal
 Approx. 50%
 Low risk
 6-8 weeks
 
 
 5th metatarsal (proximal)
 Approx. 10%
 High risk
 12-20 weeks
 
 
 Navicular
 Approx. 15%
 High risk
 12-20 weeks
 
 
 Calcaneus (heel bone)
 Approx. 10%
 Low risk
 6-8 weeks
 
 
 

 
 High-risk vs. Low-risk

 High-risk fractures are located in areas with poor blood supply and high loading. They
 require stricter offloading and have higher risk of complications.

 Pasienten ligger på ryggen med hodet hevet 30 grader. Hodet dreies raskt 90 grader til en side og holdes i 30-60 sekunder mens Øyebevegelser observeres. Deretter gjentas testen til motsatt side. Testens sensitivitet er rapportert til 89,5% (Barany Society Guidelines).

 
 Ved geotropisk variant

 Øynene slær mot bakken på begge sider, men sterkest på den affiserte siden.

 

 
 Ved apogeotropisk variant

 Øynene slær bort fra bakken, og den svakeste responsen er på den affiserte siden.

 

 
 Viktig rekkefølge

 Supine roll-testen bør ideel

Differential diagnoses for Dysautonomia?

Active Standing Test

 The simplest test: measure heart rate and blood pressure lying down, then after 2, 5, and 10 minutes in a standing position. A heart rate increase of 30 beats/min or more without significant blood pressure drop raises suspicion of POTS. This test can be performed at a GP's office or by a chiropractor.

Tilt-Table Test

 The gold standard for POTS diagnosis. The patient is secured to a table that tilts to 60-70 degrees, with continuous monitoring of heart rate and blood pressure for up to 45 minutes. Available at larger hospitals.

Blood Tests and Exclusion

 Thyroid disease, adrenal insufficiency, anemia, and other conditions that can produce similar symptoms must be ruled out. ECG and possibly Holter monitoring exclude primary heart disease.

Describe 2. Cervicogenic Dizziness (neck-related) in the context of Headache and Dizziness.

2. Cervicogenic Dizziness (neck-related)

 Dizziness caused by neck problems affects 40% of patients with neck pain. Of these, 59.7% were related to myofascial pain syndrome (muscle tension with trigger points). This often overlaps with cervicogenic headache.

 The neck contains extremely many proprioceptors (position sensors) - especially in the small muscles at the top toward the skull. When these send incorrect signals, a conflict arises between what the neck "tells" the brain and what the balance organ in the ear registers.

 
 Dizziness with head movements

 Neck pain or stiffness

 Often triggered by positions or activities

 SCM trigger points can cause both headache and dizziness

Describe causes and risk factors for Tension Headache: Everything You Need to Know.

Causes and Risk Factors

 There is rarely just one cause. Tension headache most often develops through an interplay of several factors
 1. Muscular Tension and Trigger Points

 Tender knots ( trigger points ) in neck and jaw muscles are the most consistent finding. A meta-analysis from 2022 (Pain Physician) found that chronic patients had significantly increased tenderness in pericranial muscles (SMD 1.57).

 In people with chronic tension headache, research has found an average of 3.9 trigger points per patient , compared to 1.4 in healthy controls (Couppe et al., 2007).

 2. Stress and Mental Strain

 Stress activates the sympathetic nervous system and automatically increases muscle tension. One study found that headache frequency increased by 4.3% for every 10-point increase on the stress scale. Many recognize that shoulders rise and jaw clenches during demanding periods.

 3. Sleep Disturbances

 About 50% of patients with tension headache have sleep problems (Odegard et al., 2010). Poor sleep quality lowers the pain threshold and is an independent risk factor for chronification. Many therefore experience morning headache as a result of poor night sleep.

 4. Central Sensitization

 With prolonged tension headache, changes occur in the central nervous system. The pain system becomes "overactive" - the brain registers pain signals more strongly than normal. This explains why the headache can persist even after the original triggers are gone.

 5. Posture and Ergonomics

 Forward head posture ("text neck") is associated with increased occurrence of active trigger points and tension headache. Static work in front of a screen without variation increases the risk.

 6. Genetic Factors and Hormones

 The heritability for frequent tension headache is estimated at 44-48% in twin studies. First-degree relatives have a 3.1 times higher risk of developing the condition. In women, hormonal fluctuations can also play a role - read more about hormonal headache .

 7.

Explain Headache and Dizziness to a patient.

Headache and dizziness are each among the most common complaints people seek healthcare for. When they occur simultaneously, it is rarely coincidental.

 A 2010 study showed that 51.1% of people with recurring headaches also experience dizziness as an accompanying symptom. The combination occurs three times more often than expected if the conditions were independent of each other.

 The problem is that the combination has many possible causes - from completely harmless muscular tension as in tension headache to serious pathology requiring immediate attention. Therefore, thorough assessment is essential.

Diagnostikk

 Hodepine fra muskulære årsaker diagnostiseres primært gjennom klinisk undersøkelse . Bildediagnostikk som MR eller CT er sjelden nødvendig ved typisk spenningshodepine og gir ofte funn som slitasje eller degenerasjon som ikke forklarer plagene.

 Undersøkelsen inkluderer
 Palpasjon av nakke- og ansiktsmuskulatur for å lokalisere triggerpunkter

 Vurdering av om trykk på triggerpunktet reproduserer pasientens kjente hodepine

 Holdningsvurdering inkludert fremoverlent hodefremskutt

 Nevrologisk screening for å utelukke alvorlige årsaker

 Kraniovertebral bevegelighet og nakkeleddsfunksjon

 ICHD-3 klassifisering av spenningshodepine
 Sjelden episodisk: Mindre enn 1 dag/måned

 Hyppig episodisk: 1-14 dager/måned

 Kronisk: 15 dager eller mer/måned i over 3 måneder

 HjØrnesteinen i behandling av akillestendinopati er progressiv belastningstrening. Dette hØres kanskje kontraintuitivt ut - hvorfor belaste en smertefull sene? Forskningen er imidlertid tydelig: sener trenger kontrollert belastning for å tilpasse seg og bli sterkere.

 Hva kan kiropraktoren gjøre?

 
 
 1

 
 Veiledning i ovelsesprogrammer

 Korrekt utforelse av eccentric training eller Heavy Slow Resistance er avgjørende

 

 

 
 2

 
 Belastningsstyring

 Finne riktig balanse mellom aktivitet og restitusjon, med gradvis progresjon

 

 

 
 3

 
 Bløtvevsbehandling

 Behandling av leggmuskulatur og omkringliggende strukturer som supplement

 

 

 
 4

 
 Leddmobilisering

 Vurdering og behandling av ankelledd ved nedsatt bevegelighet

 

 

 
 5

 
 Trykkbolgebehandling (ESWT)

 Kan vurderes ved kroniske tilfeller, særlig i kombinasjon med Øvelser

 

 

 

 De to gullstandard-protokollene

 
 1. Alfredson Eccentric Protocol (Sverige, 1998)

 Excentrisk haelsenk fra trappekant:

 
 3 sett x 15 repetisjoner, med både strakt og bøyd kne

 To ganger daglig (totalt 180 repetisjoner)

 Øvelsene utføres i smertesonen (0-5/10)

 Vekten okes gradvis

 
 60% suksess etter 4 måneder vs 24% for "vent og se" (Rompe 2007)

 

 
 2. Heavy Slow Resistance (Danmark, 2015)

 Tre Øvelser med tung belastning:

 
 Sittende tahev, legpress-tahev, staende tahev

 3 ganger per uke

 Langsomme bevegelser (3 sek opp, 3 sek ned)

 Progresjon fra 15RM til 6RM over 12 uker

Vurder røde flagg for Brystryggsmerter: Årsaker, Symptomer og Behandling.

Røde flagg – Når du bør søke lege umiddelbart

 

 
 Ring 113 eller oppsøk legevakt umiddelbart ved:

 
 Sterke brystsmerter som stråler til venstre arm, kjeve eller hals

 Pustevansker, tungpustethet eller klam svette

 Plutselige, intense "rivende" smerter i ryggen

 Svakhet eller lammelse i bena, tap av blåre-/tarmkontroll

 Feber kombinert med ryggsmerter

 Uforklarlig vekttap kombinert med vedvarende ryggsmerter

 
 

 
 Hjertesmerter vs. ribbeinsmerter å hvordan skille?

 Hjertesmerter: Ofte diffuse/trykkende, kommer gjerne ved anstrengelse, ledsages av svette, kvalme, pustevansker. Strøler ofte til arm, kjeve eller rygg. Endres IKKE av bevegelse eller trykk på brystet.

 Ribbeins-/muskelsmerter: Ofte skarpe/stikkende, kommer ved bestemte bevegelser eller pust. Du kan ofte peke på akkurat hvor det gjør vondt. Forverres ved trykk på stedet, rotasjon eller dyp innpust.

 Er du i tvil? Det er alltid trygt å ringe 113 eller legevakt for en vurdering. Bedre én tur for mye enn én for lite.

Beskriv årsaker og risikofaktorer for Hodepine i tinningen.

Årsaker og risikofaktorer

 Spenningshodepine

 Vanligst - 26-33% 

 Spenningshodepine er den hyppigste årsaken til tinningssmerte. Smerten beskrives typisk som et pressende band rundt hodet, ofte bilateralt. Den topper seg i alderen 30-39 år og er noe vanligere hos kvinner.

 Utløsende faktorer: Stress, dårlig søvn, langvarig skjermarbeid og muskulære spenninger i nakke og skuldre. Triggerpunkter i øvre trapezius kan gi referert smerte i et karakteristisk "rams horn"-mønster.

 Migrene

 11-15% 

 Migrene har en årlig befolkningsprevalens på 11-15% (HUNT-studiene). Kvinner rammes omtrent tre ganger så ofte som menn. Migrenesmerte er typisk pulserende og ofte ensidig, gjerne lokalisert til tinningen.

 Migrene skiller seg fra spenningshodepine ved at den ofte ledsages av kvalme, lys- og lydfølsomhet, og forverres ved fysisk aktivitet. Mange opplever også forvarsel (aura) med synsforstyrrelser for hodepinen. Noen utvikler også vestibulær migrene med episodisk vertigo.

 Kjeveleddsplager (TMD)

 5-10% 

 Temporomandibulære dysfunksjoner (TMD) gir klinisk signifikante symptomer hos 5-10% av befolkningen. Kvinner rammes 2-4 ganger oftere enn menn, med høyest forekomst i alderen 20-40 år.

 Forholdet mellom TMD og hodepine er toveis: omtrent 62% av TMD-pasienter rapporterer hodepine, og 59% av hodepinepasienter har tegn på TMD-involvering.

 Typiske symptomer: Kjevesmerter, klikkelyder ved gaping, begrenset gapeevne, og hodepine som forverres ved tygging eller kjevebruk.

 Cervikogen hodepine

 0,4-4% 

 Cervikogen hodepine utgår fra strukturer i nakken og refererer smerte til hodet, inkludert tinningen. Forekomsten i befolkningen er 0,4-4%, men utgjør 15-20% av kroniske cefalalgi-tilfeller i tertiærklinisk praksis.

 Kjennetegn: Ensidig hodepine som starter i nakken, redusert nakkebevegelse, og forverring ved bestemte nakkeposisjoner. Hodepinen bytter vanligvis ikke side.

Beskriv behandlingsalternativer for Nakkesmerter - Komplett guide til Årsaker, behandling og røde flagg.

Behandling av nakkesmerter

 

 Manuell behandling kombinert med Øvelser

 Kombinasjonen av manuell behandling og Øvelser har dokumentert effekt ved nakkesmerter. En meta-analyse fra 2023 fant at manipulativ terapi gå bedre resultater på smerte og funksjon sammenlignet med kontrollgrupper (Wang et al., 2023). Effekten er tydeligst på kort sikt.

 Hos meg på TheBackROM kombinerer jeg leddmobilisering, bløtvevsbehandling og malrettede Øvelser tilpasset din situasjon. Manipulasjon av brystvirvelsoylen kan også gi umiddelbar lindring av nakkesmerter.

 
 Hvorfor tidlig behandling lénner seg

 En studie fra 2016 sammenlignet pasienter som fikk behandling innen fire uker med dem som ventet lenger. Resultatet var tydelig: tidlig behandling ga dobbelt så stor sjanse for klinisk betydningsfull bedring på både smerte og funksjon (Horn et al., 2016). Tidlig innsats var også mer kostnadseffektivt og krevde færre behandlinger totalt.

 

 Hva kan du forvente av et behandlingsforløp?

 
 Ved akutte nakkesmerter (under 6 uker): Vanligvis 2-3 behandlinger per uke de første 2-4 ukene, deretter gradvis nedtrapping. Totalt 6-12 behandlinger.

 Ved kroniske plager (over 12 uker): 1-2 behandlinger per uke over lengre tid, kombinert med hjemmetreningsprogram.

 

 Målet er alltid at du skal bli mest mulig selvhjulpen.

 Prognose og tilbakefallsrisiko

 De fleste med nakkesmerter blir betydelig bedre, enten av seg selv eller med behandling. Det er likevel viktig å våre realistisk:

 
 50-85% av de...

Explain surgery vs. conservative treatment for Clicking, Locking and Joint Problems in the Jaw.

Surgery vs. Conservative Treatment

 What does research say about surgery for jaw joint problems?

 Important Research Findings

 5-year follow-up: Patients treated surgically and conservatively have equally good results 

 Surgery carries risk of complications

 Many who have surgery still need conservative treatment afterward

 International guidelines always recommend conservative treatment first

 When Is Surgery Considered?

 Surgery is only relevant in special situations
 After 6+ months of failed conservative treatment

 Severe structural damage (fracture, tumor)

 Persistent locking that doesn't respond to treatment

 Significant functional disability

 Surgical Options

 Arthrocentesis: Flushing the joint with saline (least invasive)

 Arthroscopy: Keyhole surgery to release the disc

 Open surgery: Rare, only for serious conditions

Beskriv Hva er en SLAP-lesjon? for SLAP-lesjon: Alt du trenger å vite.

Hva er en SLAP-lesjon?

 

 SLAP-lesjon er en skade på den Øvre delen av labrum (leddlepen) i skulderleddet, der den lange bicepssenen fester seg. "SLAP" star for "Superior Labrum Anterior to Posterior" - altså en skade som strekker seg fra foran til bak på den Øvre leddlepen.

 Labrum er en bruskring som omgir leddfaten i skulderen og bidrar til stabiliteten. Den lange bicepssenen fester seg på toppen av denne ringen, og det er her SLAP-lesjoner oppstår.

 Klassifikasjon

 SLAP-lesjoner klassifiseres i fire hovedtyper:

 
 
 Type I - Degenerative forandringer

 

 Slitasje og frynser i labrum uten avløsning. Vanlig aldersforandring. Krever sjelden behandling.

 

 
 
 Type II - Avløsning av labrum og bicepsfeste

 Vanligst
 

 Labrum og bicepsfestet loster fra leddfaten. Dette er den mest klinisk relevante typen og den som oftest diskuteres i forhold til kirurgi.

 

 
 
 Type III - "Botte-hank"-rift

 

 En del av labrum rives av og kan henge ned i leddet som en botte-hank. Kan gi mekaniske symptomer.

 

 
 
 Type IV - Rift som involverer bicepssenen

 

 Kombinasjon av type III med at riftten strekker seg inn i bicepssenen.

 

 
 
 6%
 av skulderartroskopier
 

 
 Type II
 vanligste type
 

 
 20-40 Ør
 typisk aldersgruppe

Beskriv Fordelene med kortison for Kortisoninjeksjon i skulder: Venn eller fiende?.

Fordelene med kortison

 

 Kortison har sin plass i behandlingen av skulderplager. Her er situasjonene der det kan våre nyttig:

 
 Når kortison kan våre et godt valg

 
 Akutt, intens betennelse: Når smerten er så kraftig at du ikke klarer å gjøre Øvelser

 for å muliggjøre rehabilitering: Smertelindring slik at du kan starte opptrening

 Diagnostisk verktøy: Hvis injeksjonen gir lindring, bekrefter det at problemet er lokalt

 Akutt bursitt: Betennelse i slimpose responderer ofte godt

 Frossen skulder: Kan hjelpe i den smertefulle første fasen

 
 

 
 
 70-80%
 opplever initial bedring
 

 
 24-48t
 tid til effekt
 

 
 6-8 uker
 typisk varighet
 

 

 
 Kortison som "vindusÅpner"

 Den kanskje beste bruken av kortison er som et "vindu" for rehabilitering. Injeksjonen gir midlertidig smertelindring slik at du kan gjennomføre Øvelser og fysisk behandling som adresserer den underliggende Årsaken. Kortison alene uten oppfølgende rehabilitering gir sjelden varig bedring.

Describe Referred pain - pain in the wrong place for Trigger Points in Arm and Forearm.

Referred pain - pain in the wrong place

 

 The most confusing thing about trigger points is referred pain: pain is felt in a
 completely different place from where the problem is. This explains why many get the wrong diagnosis.

 
 Common referred pain patterns in the arm

 
 Extensors (top of forearm): Referred pain to elbow and back of hand - resembles tennis elbow

 Flexors (underside of forearm): Referred pain to wrist and fingers - resembles carpal tunnel

 Brachioradialis: Referred pain to thumb base and wrist

 Scalene muscles (neck): Referred pain down into arm and fingers - resembles
 radiculopathy

 Subscapularis (shoulder): Referred pain to wrist and back of upper arm

 
 

 
 Common misdiagnoses

 Because of referred pain, trigger points are often misdiagnosed as:

 
 Tennis elbow (lateral epicondylitis)

 Carpal tunnel syndrome

 Cervical radiculopathy (neck nerve root)

 De Quervain's tenosynovitis

 Frozen shoulder

Describe causes and risk factors for Shoulder Impingement.

Causes and risk factors

 The cause of subacromial pain syndrome is usually multifactorial. Several factors play a role
 Overuse and repetitive movements

 Most common 

 Repetitive overhead arm movements are the most frequent trigger. This applies to both occupations (painters, electricians, plumbers) and sports (swimming, tennis, handball, volleyball).

 Muscular imbalance

 Weakness in the rotator cuff and scapular stabilizers (the muscles that control the shoulder blade) causes the upper arm bone to migrate upward, narrowing the subacromial space. This is one of the most important modifiable risk factors.

 Posture-related factors

 A forward-leaning posture with protracted shoulders (rounded upper back) alters shoulder biomechanics and can contribute to irritation of subacromial structures.

 Risk factors

 Overhead work/sports: Painters, swimmers, handball players

 Age over 40: Degenerative changes in tendons and bursa

 Poor posture: Protracted shoulders, increased thoracic kyphosis

 Previous shoulder injury: Altered biomechanics after trauma

 Diabetes and metabolic disease: Generally increased risk of tendon problems

 Overload as the main driver

 In most cases, the issue is that the load over time exceeds the tissue's tolerance threshold. This is why gradual progressive training and load management are so central to treatment.

Beskriv Hvem bor du velge? for Kiropraktor vs Naprapat: Hva er forskjellen og hvem bor du velge?.

Hvem bor du velge?

 

 
 Velg kiropraktor hvis:

 
 Du kan trenge sykemelding - bare kiropraktor (sammen med lege og manuellterapeut) kan skrive sykemelding

 Du trenger bildediagnostikk - kiropraktorer kan rekvirere MR, rontgen og CT direkte uten at du ma via fastlegen

 Du vil ha en behandler som kan handtere det meste - kiropraktorens utvidede rettigheter betyr at du ofte slipper a ga via andre instanser

 Du har nevrologiske symptomer - kiropraktorens medisinske utdanning er spesielt relevant ved mistanke om nervepavirkning

 Du onsker kortere, mer fokuserte behandlinger - kiropraktisk tradisjon vektlegger effektive, malrettede intervensjoner

 
 

 
 Velg naprapat hvis:

 
 Du onsker lengre behandlingstid - naprapater bruker ofte mer tid per konsultasjon

 Du foretrekker mye muskelarbeid - naprapatisk tilnarming vektlegger ofte blotvevsbehandling

 Du liker myke teknikker - naprapater bruker generelt mykere mobiliseringsteknikker

 Du har hatt god erfaring med naprapat tidligere - personlig erfaring og relasjon med behandler er viktig

 
 

 
 Det viktigste: Finn en god behandler

 Uansett tittel er den individuelle behandlerens kompetanse og erfaring avgjorende. En dyktig naprapat kan gi bedre resultat enn en middelmadig kiropraktor - og omvendt.

 

 Spor gjerne om:

 
 Behandlerens erfaring med din type plage

 Hvordan de vurderer og behandler

 Hvor mange behandlinger de forventer

Prognosis - What to Expect?

 

 
 Generally Good Prognosis

 Up to 95% of patients respond well to conservative treatment with significant pain
 reduction within 1-3 months. Most improve significantly within the first few weeks.

 Maintenance training 2 times per week can prevent recurrence.

 Pregnancy-Related SI Joint Pain

 
 Most improve within 3-4 months after delivery

 25% still have pain after 3 months, only 10% after 8 months

 8-10% have persistent problems 1-2 years postpartum

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Weak Feet: The Root Cause Most People Overlook.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 How long does it take to strengthen the feet?

 Noticeable improvements are typically seen after 4-8 weeks of consistent training. The Liverpool study showed 57% strength increase after 6 months with minimalist shoes. Foot training should be viewed as maintenance - just like any other exercise.

 

 
 Is barefoot walking safe?

 For most people, gradual barefoot walking is safe and beneficial. Start indoors on soft surfaces and increase gradually. People with diabetes, neuropathy, or reduced sensation in their feet should be careful and consult a healthcare professional first.

 

 
 Can I train my feet even if I have flat feet?

 Yes, absolutely. Research (Huang 2022 meta-analysis) shows that foot training can increase arch strength and improve function even in people with flat feet. Flexible flat foot often responds well to strength training.

 

 
 Should I throw away my orthotics?

 Not necessarily. If you have diabetes, severe deformities, or specific medical indications, orthotics may still be important. For non-specific problems, gradual weaning combined with foot training may be a good alternative. Discuss with a professional.

 

 
 Can a chiropractor help with weak feet?

 Yes. Chiropractors assess the entire musculoskeletal system and can identify whether foot problems are due to local conditions or compensations from hips, pelvis, or back. Treatment often includes joint mobilization, soft tissue work, and guidance on targeted foo...

Bent Elbow Most Common 

 When the elbow is bent, the ulnar nerve is stretched and compressed. Prolonged elbow flexion (sleeping,

 Leaning your elbow on armrests, tables, or car door armrests over time puts direct pressure on the

 elbow bends.

 Elbow fractures, dislocations, or arthritis can narrow the tunnel and irritate the nerve.

Describe why does the hole cause symptoms? for Superior Canal Dehiscence Syndrome.

Why Does the Hole Cause Symptoms?

 The inner ear normally has two "windows" - the oval window where sound enters, and the round window that provides pressure equalization. When a hole develops in the semicircular canal, an abnormal "third window" is created that changes how sound and pressure affect the balance organ.

 This third window causes
 Air-conducted sound is diverted away from the cochlea, causing hearing loss in low frequencies

 Bone-conducted sound gets enhanced access to the inner ear fluid, explaining hypersensitivity to internal body sounds

 Sound and pressure changes create abnormal fluid movement that stimulates balance cells

Du er en rask klinisk tekstassistent. Generer korte, presise kliniske oppsummeringer for kiropraktisk dokumentasjon.
Gi en strukturert klinisk oversikt over Kiropraktor vs fastlege for ryggsmerter: Hvem bor du ga til?.

Hva gjor fastlegen for ryggsmerter?: En typisk fastlegekonsultasjon for ryggsmerter varer 10–15 minutter. Det er kort tid, men fastleger er trenet til a bruke den effektivt.

Hva gjor kiropraktoren for ryggsmerter?: En forstekonsultasjon hos kiropraktor varer typisk 30–60 minutter. Det gir tid til grundig undersokelse og behandling i samme time.

Sammenligning: Fastlege vs kiropraktor: Tabellen under gir en oversikt over de viktigste praktiske forskjellene mellom fastlege og kiropraktor for ryggsmerter.

Nar bor du til fastlege forst?: Det finnes situasjoner der fastlegen er riktig forstevalg. Noen av dem er akutte og krever rask medisinsk vurdering.

Nar kan du ga direkte til kiropraktor?: For de fleste vanlige ryggplager kan du trygt ga rett til kiropraktor. Kiropraktorer er trenet til a gjenkjenne rode flagg, og henviser deg videre hvis de finner noe som krever medisinsk vurdering.

Hva sier retningslinjene?: Internasjonale retningslinjer er tydelige pa at manuell behandling har en plass i behandlingen av ryggsmerter — og at ikke-medikamentell behandling bor forsokes forst.

Samarbeid mellom fastlege og kiropraktor: I praksis fungerer fastlege og kiropraktor best som et lag. De utfyller hverandre — og pasientene tjener pa at behandlerne kommuniserer.

Ofte stilte sporsmal: Nei. Kiropraktor har vart primarkontakt i Norge siden 2001. Du kan bestille time direkte uten a ga via fastlegen.

Usikker pa hvem du bor kontakte?: Du trenger ikke velge en gang for alle. Bruk fastlegen nar du trenger medisiner, bred utredning eller lang sykemelding. Bruk kiropraktoren nar du har mekaniske plager og vil ha rask tilgang til undersokelse og behandling. Og bruk begge nar situasjonen krever det.

Describe treatment options for Meniere's Disease.

Treatment

 

 There is no cure for Meniere's disease. The goal of treatment is to reduce attack frequency, relieve symptoms and improve quality of life.

 Conservative Treatment and Lifestyle

 
 Salt Reduction

 A stable, low salt intake (<1500-2000 mg sodium daily) is often recommended as first-line treatment. The theory is that this can stabilize the fluid balance in the inner ear. The Cochrane review from 2018 found no randomized studies supporting this, but many patients report improvement.

 

 Medical Treatment

 
 Betahistine (Betaserc)

 The most commonly used medication in Europe. The BEMED study (2016) found no significant difference between betahistine and placebo, but the medication is well tolerated and is often tried for 3-6 months.

 

 Vestibular Rehabilitation

 AAO-HNS recommends vestibular rehabilitation for patients with chronic unsteadiness between attacks. A meta-analysis from 2023 found moderate effect on quality of life.

 
 Important About Vestibular Rehabilitation

 Vestibular rehabilitation is not recommended during acute attacks - it is well-documented when vertigo episodes are under control.

 

 What Can the Chiropractor Contribute?

 Chiropractors cannot treat the fluid accumulation in the inner ear itself. But many people with Meniere's disease develop secondary problems that I can help with:

 
 Neck and shoulder tension: Chronic stress and abnormal head position during attacks often lead to muscle tightness, which can cause cervicogenic di...

Differential diagnoses for Trigger Points and Myofascial Pain Syndrome in the Neck?

Static loading and poor ergonomics

 Prolonged desk work, screen use with forward head posture, and repetitive work are by far the most common causes. Office workers have an average of 6 active and 10-11 latent trigger points.

Muscular overload

 Repetitive movements, heavy lifting, or sudden increased training load.

Stress and tension

 Psychological stress often leads to chronic muscle tension, especially in the neck and shoulders.

Other factors

 Sleep problems and fatigue: Poor sleep reduces the muscles' ability to recover

 Vitamin D deficiency: Approximately one-third of MPS patients have low vitamin D levels

 Trauma: Among whiplash patients, 55-65% have trigger points in the levator scapulae

Describe The Most Important Examination Finding in the context of Costochondritis and Chest Pain.

Sharp, stabbing or aching pain along the breastbone, often on one side

 Worsening with deep breathing, coughing and sneezing

 Increased pain with movement of the upper body or arms

 Local tenderness that can be reproduced by pressing on the cartilage connections

 Radiation along the ribs to the back, or to arms and shoulders

 
 

 Pain can vary from mild to intense. Many describe a feeling that "something is stuck" in the chest.
 Symptoms can last from a few weeks to several months without treatment.

 

 
 
 
 5
 Diagnostics

 

 Costochondritis is a clinical diagnosis - there is no blood test or imaging that
 confirms the condition. The diagnosis is made based on medical history and physical examination.

 
 The Most Important Examination Finding

 Pain can be reproduced by pressing on the affected cartilage connections. This is called
 reproducible tenderness and is characteristic of the condition.
 

 

 When is Imaging Necessary?

 X-ray and MRI are rarely indicated for typical costochondritis. Imaging may be relevant to rule out other
 causes with atypical symptoms, prolonged course, or suspected underlying disease.

 
 Validated Clinical Tool

 Chest Wall Syndrome Clinical Prediction Rule (Gencer et al., BMC Family Practice, 2012) uses six
 factors to identify chest wall syndrome with 88.6% specificity: localized muscle tension, stabbing pain
 character, reproducible pain on palpation, absence of cough, pain that is not retrosternal or pressing,
 and no known coronary disease.

Differential diagnoses for Hormonal Headache and Menstrual Migraine?

Pure menstrual migraine

 7-14% of migraine women 

 Migraine attacks that only occur in connection with menstruation (day -2 to +3 of the cycle). No attacks at other times. Often characterized by longer duration and poorer response to triptans than regular migraine .

Menstrually-related migraine

 Most common - approx. 50% 

 Migraine attacks that often occur around menstruation, but also occur at other times in the cycle. There must be a clear increase in attack frequency around the period to qualify.

Hormonal headache from birth control

 Headache that occurs during the pill-free week when estrogen levels drop. Can also be experienced when starting or switching contraception.

Hormonal headache in menopause

 Unpredictable hormonal fluctuations in perimenopause can cause irregular headaches. Many experience worsening during this phase, but improvement after menopause. Some develop chronic daily headache during this period.

Vurder røde flagg: 6 år gutt med nakkesmerter etter trampoline-hopp. Normal kraft i armer. Foreldrene rapporterer kortvarig nummenhet i armene som gikk over. Nek perkusjonsøm C4.

RØDE FLAGG IDENTIFISERT: Mistanke om cervikal skade hos barn.

Funn:
- Traume-mekanisme (trampoline = aksial belastning)
- Transient nevrologisk utfall (forbigående nummenhet i armer)
- Fokal perkusjonsømhet C4
- Barns cervicalcolumna er anatomisk mer sårbar (ligamentær laxitet, stort hode)

Transient nevrologisk utfall etter traume kan indikere ustabil skade eller forbigående medullakompresjon (SCIWORA).

HANDLING: Immobiliser cervicalcolumna. Akutt CT og MR. INGEN manipulasjon. Barnelege/barneortoped. Ring 113.

Beskriv Kirurgi i kontekst av Biceps tendinopati: Alt du trenger å vite.

PRP (Platelet-Rich Plasma)

 Injeksjon av blodplater fra pasientens eget blod. Evidensen er fortsatt begrenset, men noen studier viser lovende resultater for seneproblemer.

 

 Kirurgi

 Kirurgi vurderes kun når konservativ behandling over 3-6 måneder ikke gir tilfredsstillende bedring. Alternativer inkluderer:

 
 Tenotomi: Senen kuttes og får trekke seg ned (enklere, raskere rehabilitering)

 Tenodese: Senen festes på nytt til overarmsbeinet (bevarer styrke og kontur)

 

 
 Prognose etter kirurgi

 Bade tenotomi og tenodese gir gode resultater hos de fleste. Valget avhenger av alder, aktivitetsniva og kosmetiske preferanser. Tenodese foretrekkes ofte hos yngre, aktive pasienter.

Describe treatment options for Fibromyalgia with Chest Pain.

Treatment

 

 What does the research say?

 EULAR (European League Against Rheumatism) published revised guidelines in 2017. Exercise is the
 a key treatment approach with a strong recommendation. A network meta-analysis from 2024 (51 studies,
 2873 patients) showed that water exercise is well-documented short-term, while strength training is best
 long-term.

 
 Treatment options

 
 Exercise (strong recommendation): Water exercise well-documented short-term,
 strength training best long-term. 51 studies with 2873 patients document the effect.

 Massage therapy (5+ weeks): Shows moderate effect for pain, anxiety and depression.
 Myofascial release (soft tissue treatment) had the most suitable effect.

 Manual treatment/chiropractic: EULAR guidelines give a "strong against"
 recommendation for chiropractic for fibromyalgia. A systematic review (Ernst, 2009) concluded
 "insufficient evidence".

 
 

 What can the chiropractor do?

 Given the limited evidence, a consultation is primarily about:

 
 Thorough examination - ruling out other causes of chest pain

 Soft tissue treatment - gentle treatment of muscle tightness, not aggressive
 manipulation

 Exercise guidance - help getting started with adapted exercise

 Pain management - explanation of central sensitization, sleep hygiene, stress
 management

 

 
 It is important to be honest:

 Chiropractic is not a first-line treatment for fibromyalgia based on current research. Exercise and
 cognitive therapy have far better e...

Repetitive manual work Most common 

 Manual labor like carpentry, plumbing, painting. Repetitive gripping and twisting movements over time.

Office work

 Prolonged mouse and keyboard use, especially with poor ergonomics. Often combined with tennis elbow.
 See our article on mouse arm .

Throwing sports

 Baseball, handball, javelin throwing. Repetitive throwing motions strain the inside of the elbow.

Golf (5-10% of cases)

 Actually only a small proportion. Most common in beginners with incorrect technique.

Beskriv årsaker og risikofaktorer for Metatarsalgi.

Årsaker og risikofaktorer

 Metatarsalgi utvikles når forfoten utsettes for unormalt høy eller langvarig belastning.

 Vanlige årsaker

 Feil fottoy Vanligste årsak 

 Hoyhalte sko, for trange sko, eller sko uten tilstrekkelig demping økerbelastningen på forfoten betydelig.

 Biomekaniske faktorer

 Hoy fotbue (pes cavus), stiv ankel, lang 2. ta (Mortons ta), eller hypermobile ledd kan fore til ujevn belastningsfordeling.

 Overbelastning

 For rask okning i aktivitet, langvarig staende arbeid, eller intensiv løpetrening kan overbelaste forfoten.

 Hallux valgus Ofte samtidig 

 Skjev storta fører til at vekten flyttes til 2. og 3. metatarsal, som blir overbelastet. Hallux rigidus kan gi lignende belastningsendringer.

 Risikofaktorer

 Overvekt (Økt belastning per steg)

 Alder over 50 (tynnere fettputer under foten)

 Høye heler (skyver vekten fremover)

 Diabetes (endret sensibilitet og blodgjennomstromning)

 Revmatoid artritt

 Idrett med mye loping og hopping - kan også fore til akillestendinopati eller stressfraktur

Beskriv Ofte stilte spørsmål for Vedvarende Plager Etter Hjernerystelse.

Ofte stilte spørsmål

 

 
 Hvor lenge varer svimmelhet etter hjernerystelse?

 For de fleste går svimmelheten over i løpet av dager til noen uker. Med vestibular rehabilitering er de fleste betydelig bedre innen 4-8 uker. Rundt 10-15% får vedvarende plager utover 3 måneder, og noen kan utvikle PPPD (kronisk svimmelhet).

 

 
 Kan kiropraktor behandle plager etter hjernerystelse?

 Ja, kiropraktorer med kompetanse på vestibular rehabilitering kan gi effektiv behandling. Kombinasjonen av vestibular rehabilitering og nakkebehandling har sterk forskningsstotte.

 

 
 Bør jeg unnga aktivitet hvis jeg er svimmel etter hjernerystelse?

 Nei, langvarig inaktivitet kan faktisk forsinke bedringen. Etter 24-48 timers relativ hvile bør du gradvis gjenoppta aktivitet tilpasset symptomene.

 

 
 Trenger jeg MR eller CT?

 Ved typisk hjernerystelse og PCS viser bildediagnostikk normale funn - skaden er funksjonell, ikke strukturell. MR/CT er indisert ved røde flagg-symptomer for å utelukke blodning eller strukturskade.

How is Vestibular Neuritis diagnosed?

Diagnosis

 

 Vestibular neuritis is primarily a clinical diagnosis. The most important thing is to distinguish it from stroke in the cerebellum or brainstem, which can cause very similar symptoms. Approximately 25% of patients with acute vestibular syndrome may have central nervous system causes.

 The HINTS Examination

 HINTS (Head Impulse, Nystagmus, Test of Skew) is a three-step eye examination that, in cases of acute dizziness, has proven more sensitive than MRI for detecting stroke in the first 24-48 hours. Performed by trained clinicians, HINTS is 96.5% sensitive and 84-96% specific.

 
 Head Impulse Test

 Rapid passive head rotation while the patient focuses. In vestibular neuritis, the gaze will "slip" and must be corrected.

 

 
 Nystagmus

 In vestibular neuritis, nystagmus is unidirectional - the eyes beat the same direction regardless of gaze direction.

 

 
 Test of Skew

 Alternating covering of the eyes. Vertical readjustment indicates brainstem lesion.

Describe Three Main Categories of Dizziness for Types of Dizziness: How to Tell the Difference Between Different Forms.

Three Main Categories of Dizziness

 

 Before we get into specific diagnoses, it's helpful to understand the three main types of dizziness:

 
 Vertigo - Room Spinning

 With vertigo, you experience that you or your surroundings are rotating. There's a clear sensation of movement even when you're sitting still. This is almost always caused by problems in the balance organ in the inner ear.

 
 Typical description: "The room is spinning", "I'm whirling around"

 Common causes: BPPV, vestibular neuritis, Meniere's disease

 Often accompanied by: Nausea, vomiting, nystagmus (involuntary eye movements)

 
 

 
 Unsteadiness - Rocking or Swaying Sensation

 With unsteadiness, you feel off-balance without the room spinning. It can be described as standing on a boat deck or walking on an unstable surface.

 
 Typical description: "Like being on a boat", "I feel unstable"

 Common causes: Cervicogenic dizziness, PPPD, vestibular hypofunction

 Often accompanied by: Neck pain, anxiety, worsening in crowds

 
 

 
 Lightheadedness - Foggy Head

 With lightheadedness, you feel "light-headed", distant, or like you're about to faint. There's no clear sensation of movement.

 
 Typical description: "Foggy", "almost like I'm going to faint"

 Common causes: Orthostatic hypotension, anemia, medications, anxiety

 Often accompanied by: Palpitations, sweating, vision darkening when standing up

Explain treatment for Anterior Canal BPPV: The Rare Variant.

Treatment

 What Can the Chiropractor Do?

 Treatment of anterior canal BPPV involves repositioning maneuvers intended to move the crystals out of the semicircular canal. A systematic review found an overall treatment success of 85.6% (Anagnostou 2015).

 Yacovino Maneuver - First Choice

 Particularly suitable for anterior canal BPPV because it does not require identification of the affected side. Success rate: 78.8% (Anagnostou 2015).

 Epley Maneuver (Reversed)

 Reversed Epley from the unaffected side has shown 75.9% success. Requires identification of the affected side.

 Treatment Course and Realistic Expectations

 60-70% achieve symptom relief after 1-2 treatments

 20-30% need 3-5 treatments

 10% may require longer follow-up or alternative approach

Beskriv Trinn 6 - Retur til kamp i kontekst av Hjernerystelse i Idrett: Når Kan Du Spille Igjen?.

Trinn 6 - Retur til kamp

 Uhindret deltakelse

 

 Minimum tidsbruk: Med ett trinn per dag er tidligste retur til kamp 6 dager etter symptomfrihet. I praksis tar det ofte lenger tid, særlig for barn og ungdom.

 

 
 
 
 6
 Når bedres de fleste?

 

 Voksne (over 18 år)

 
 7 dager: 85% symptomfrie

 14 dager: 80-90% klinisk restituert

 30 dager: De fleste fullt friske

 

 Barn og ungdom bruker lenger tid

 
 4 uker: Ca. 70% restituert

 Gjennomsnittlig tid til full klarering: 20 dager

 Forlenget bedring over 3 måneder forekommer, særlig hos jenter

 

 Risikofaktorer for forlenget bedring

 
 Konsentrasjonsvansker ved første undersøkelse (3,4 ganger økt risiko)

 Tidligere angst, depresjon eller søvnproblemer (2,5 ganger økt risiko)

 Kvinnelig kjønn (1,7 ganger økt risiko)

 Bevisstløshet eller hukommelsestap ved skaden (1,9 ganger økt risiko)

 
 

 
 
 
 7
 Hjelp etter hjernerystelse

Describe causes and risk factors for Spinal Stenosis.

Causes and Risk Factors

 Spinal stenosis is almost always caused by age-related changes in the spine. Over 95% of cases are
 degenerative stenosis.

 Facet Joint Osteoarthritis

 Wear in the small joints at the back of the spine leading to thickening and bone spurs.

 Thickening of Ligamentum Flavum

 The yellow ligament located behind the spinal canal can become thicker with age and take up space
 from the nerves.

 Disc Degeneration

 The discs between the vertebrae lose height and can bulge into the canal. This can also lead to herniation .

 Osteophytes

 Bone spurs that grow into the spinal canal or nerve exits.

 Risk Factors with Documented Association

 Age over 60: 3-5 times higher prevalence

 Obesity: BMI over 30 gives more than double the risk

 Diabetes: Found in 29% of stenosis patients vs 10% in the general population

 Spondylolisthesis : Vertebral slippage can
 contribute to stenosis

What is the prognosis for AC Joint Osteoarthritis: Everything You Need to Know?

Prognosis

 

 The prognosis for AC joint osteoarthritis is generally good with conservative treatment.

 
 The Positive:

 
 Most achieve good symptom control without surgery

 93% with weightlifter's shoulder improve with activity modification

 Surgery has good results in those who need it

Describe symptoms and signs of Dizzy When Lying Down? What You Need to Know About BPPV.

Symptoms

 

 The classic symptom is brief, intense rotational vertigo triggered by specific head movements:

 
 Typical triggers

 
 Lying down in bed

 Turning over in bed (especially to one side)

 Tilting the head back (e.g., looking up into a cupboard)

 Rising quickly from a lying position

 
 

 
 Typical course

 
 Delay: 5-10 seconds after the head movement before the dizziness starts

 Duration: Typically under 60 seconds - rarely over one minute

 Additional symptoms: Nausea is common, vomiting occurs with severe episodes

 After-effect: Mild lightheadedness and unsteadiness for minutes to hours afterward

 
 

 
 This is NOT typical for BPPV

 The following symptoms suggest a different cause and require further investigation:

 
 Hearing loss or tinnitus

 Pressure or fullness in the ear

 Persistent dizziness (not just with head movements)

 Neurological symptoms such as double vision, numbness, or paralysis

Describe Types of Sports Injuries for Sports Injuries - Complete Guide.

Types of Sports Injuries

 

 Acute vs. Overuse Injuries

 Sports injuries fall into two main categories, each requiring different treatment approaches:

 
 Acute Injuries

 Result from a single traumatic event - a fall, collision, or sudden movement. Examples include ankle sprains, muscle tears, and ligament ruptures. These typically cause immediate pain and swelling.

 

 
 Overuse Injuries

 Develop gradually from repetitive stress over time. Examples include tendinopathies (Achilles, patellar), stress fractures, and shin splints. Pain often starts mild and worsens if training continues unchanged.

 

 Common Sports Injuries

 
 Muscle strains: Tears in muscle fibers, often in hamstrings, quads, or calves

 Ligament sprains: Stretching or tearing of ligaments, commonly ankle or knee

 Tendinopathies: Degeneration of tendons from repetitive loading

 Stress fractures: Small cracks in bone from cumulative overload

 Joint injuries: Cartilage damage, labral tears, meniscus injuries

Vurder røde flagg for Vondt i Hoften? - Komplett guide.

Akutt selvhjelp: Hva du kan gjøre nå

 

 Mens du venter på behandling, er det viktig å ikke irritere vevet unoedig. Her er "brannslukkingstiltakene" jeg anbefaler:

 
 
 1
 Slik bør du sove

 

 
 Nattsmerter er sværtvanlig ved hoftesmerter, særlig ved seneproblemer på utsiden (GTPS). Når du ligger på siden, komprimeres senene mot benet - som å klemme en sene mellom to harde flater.

 
 Unngå å ligge på den vonde siden: Dette Økerkompresjonen på senene.

 Bruk pute mellom knærne: Hvis du ligger på den friske siden, holder en tykk pute fra kne til ankel hoften noeytral.

 Ligge på ryggen: Ofte den beste stillingen. Eventuelt med en pute under knærne.

 
 

 

 
 
 2
 Slik bør du sitte og stå

 

 
 
 Ikke sitt med bena i kryss: Dette strekker senene på utsiden av hoften.

 Unngå å "henge" på hoften: Når du står, fordel vekten likt på begge ben.

 Ved lyskesmerter: Senk stolen litt eller vipp setet forover for å Åpne hoftevinkelen.

Hva er prognosen for Krystallsyke (BPPV)?

Prognose

 

 BPPV er en godartet tilstand med svært god prognose. Reposisjonsmanvrer gir umiddelbar bedring hos de fleste.

 Restsvimmelhet etter behandling

 31-61% av pasientene rapporterer vedvarende lett svimmelhet eller ustohet etter vellykket behandling, selv om nystagmus og posisjonsell vertigo er borte. Denne restsvimmelheten varer vanligvis i median 10 dager og forsvinner som regel innen 3 måneder. Hos noen kan dette utvikle seg til PPPD (vedvarende postural-perseptuell svimmelhet).

 Tilbakefall er vanlig

 
 Ca. 15-23% opplever tilbakefall innen første Ør

 5-Ørs tilbakefallsrate er rundt 40%

 Opp til 50% kan oppleve ny episode innen 5 Ør

 

 Forebygging av tilbakefall

 D-vitamintilskudd hos pasienter med påvist mangel kan redusere risikoen for nye episoder. En meta-analyse viste signifikant reduksjon i tilbakefallsrate (relativ risiko 0,37).

Hvordan diagnostiseres Horisontal Kanal BPPV?

Diagnostikk

 

 Supine roll-test (gullstandarden)

 Pasienten ligger på ryggen med hodet hevet 30 grader. Hodet dreies raskt 90 grader til en side og holdes i 30-60 sekunder mens Øyebevegelser observeres. Deretter gjentas testen til motsatt side. Testens sensitivitet er rapportert til 89,5% (Barany Society Guidelines).

 
 Ved geotropisk variant

 Øynene slær mot bakken på begge sider, men sterkest på den affiserte siden.

 

 
 Ved apogeotropisk variant

 Øynene slær bort fra bakken, og den svakeste responsen er på den affiserte siden.

 

 
 Viktig rekkefølge

 Supine roll-testen bør ideelt utføres får Dix-Hallpike-testen, da Dix-Hallpike kan flytte krystaller og påvirke resultatene.

 

 
 Røde flagg - kontakt lege umiddelbart ved:

 
 Svimmelhet som varer kontinuerlig over 2 minutter (BPPV gir korte anfall)

 Plutselig hØrselstap eller kraftig Øresus

 Dobbeltsyn eller andre synsforstyrrelser

 Kraftig hodepine ulikt tidligere opplevd

 Ansiktslammelse, nummenhet eller taleforstyrrelser

 Koordinasjonsproblemer eller ustå gange

What can you do yourself?

 

 You can treat many trigger points yourself with simple techniques:

 
 Self-massage technique

 
 Find the tender point by palpating the muscles

 Press with moderate force (5-7 on a scale to 10)

 Hold pressure for 30-90 seconds until pain subsides

 Gently stretch the muscle afterward

 Repeat 2-3 times daily

 
 Tip: Use a tennis ball against the wall for hard-to-reach points in the upper arm.

 

 Preventive measures

 
 Take breaks: Regular micro-breaks during repetitive work

 Stretch: Daily stretching exercises for forearm muscles

 Ergonomics: Correct work position at computer

 Warm up: Before physical activity involving arms

 Stress management: Stress increases muscle tension

Describe symptoms and signs of Sciatica: Everything You Need to Know.

Symptoms of True Sciatica

 

 Classic symptoms include pain from the lower back/buttock, down the back of the thigh, below the knee,
 potentially to the foot and toes. The pain pattern depends on which nerve root is affected:

 
 L4 root

 
 Pain to the front of the thigh and inner calf

 Weakened knee extension

 
 

 
 L5 root (L4-L5 herniation)

 
 Pain to the outer calf and top of the foot

 Weakened toe dorsiflexion

 
 

 
 S1 root (L5-S1 herniation)

 
 Pain to the back of the calf and outer foot

 Weakened toe plantar flexion, reduced Achilles reflex

 
 

 Pain quality and provocation

 
 Pain quality: Sharp, burning, electric. Often described as "current" through the leg.
 

 Worsening: Coughing, sneezing, straining, sitting, forward bending typically
 increases pain.

 Relief: Lying on your back with bent knees, gentle movement.

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Osteitis Pubis - Chiropractor in Oslo.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 Can I exercise with osteitis pubis?

 Yes, but you should modify your training. Avoid activities that provoke pain
 (kicking, jumping, rapid direction changes). Swimming, cycling and upper body strength training can
 often be continued. Gradual increase in loading under guidance is key to successful rehabilitation.
 

 

 
 How long does it take to recover?

 With structured rehabilitation, most return to full activity within 3-6 months. Without active treatment, symptoms can last 8-12 months or longer.

 

 
 Can a chiropractor help with osteitis pubis?

 Yes. Chiropractors can offer manual treatment of pelvic and hip joints, soft tissue treatment and individually tailored exercise programs. Many patients report good results from multimodal chiropractic treatment combined with rehabilitation exercises.

Describe When You Don't Breathe With Your Belly for Breathing, Stress and Back.

When You Don't Breathe With Your Belly

 

 Dysfunctional Breathing Is More Common Than You Think

 Approximately 6-10% of the general population has dysfunctional breathing (Thomas et
 al., 2005; Boulding et al., 2016). Among asthma patients, this rises to 29-47%.

 Dysfunctional breathing means you use the wrong muscles. Instead of letting the diaphragm do the work,
 the body recruits accessory muscles in the neck and shoulders - muscles that are actually meant for
 short-term effort.

 
 The Vicious Cycle

 
 Accessory muscles overworked

 →
 Neck and shoulder pain

 →
 Stress response increases

 →
 Breathing becomes more shallow

 

 

 
 Signs That You're Breathing Wrong

 
 Shoulders rise during inhalation (instead of the belly expanding)

 Feeling of never getting enough air, even at rest

 Tension in neck and shoulders

 Frequent sighing or yawning

 Fatigue that isn't explained by lack of sleep

Beskriv Ofte stilte spørsmål for Pust, Stress og Rygg.

Ofte stilte spørsmål

 

 
 Kan dårlig holdning virkelig påvirke pusten?

 Ja. Studier viser at hyperkyfose reduserer diafragmabevegelse med opptil 35% og lungekapasitet med 0,25-0,81 liter. Dette er målbare, fysiologiske endringer.

 

 
 Hjelper det å "rette seg opp" bevisst?

 På kort sikt ja, men aktiv muskelbruk er slitsomt. Målet er å forbedre thorakal bevegelighet slik at en god holdning krever mindre anstrengelse. Trening og mobilisering er mer effektivt enn bare å "tenke på å sitte rett".

 

 
 Kan pusteØvelser virkelig redusere stress?

 Forskning viser moderat effekt (effektstørrelse 0,35). Forlenget utpust aktiverer det parasympatiske nervesystemet og kan senke kortisolnivåer. Effekten kommer etter noen dagers regelmessig Øving.

 

 
 Hvor lenge må jeg gjøre Øvelser får det hjelper?

 De fleste studier viser effekt etter 4-8 uker med regelmessig trening (2-3 Økter per uke). PusteØvelser kan gi umiddelbar avspenningseffekt, men varige endringer krever tid.

 

 
 Er det farlig å ha krum rygg?

 Ikke nødvendigvis. Mange lever fint med varierende grad av kyfose. Problemet oppstar når stivheten begrenser funksjon eller gir plager. En fleksibel kyfose er mindre problematisk enn en rigid en.

 

 
 Bør jeg ta røntgen eller MR?

 Vanligvis ikke ved typiske holdningsplager. Klinisk undersøkelse gir ofte tilstrekkelig informasjon. Bildediagnostikk kan våre aktuelt ved mistanke om strukturelle Årsaker som Scheuermanns sykdom eller kompresjonsbrudd.

 

 
 Påvirker holdni...

Beskriv diagnostikk for Ribbeinslasning vs. Ribbeinsbrudd.

Diagnostikk

 Mange tror at røntgen er fasiten for å avdekke ribbeinsbrudd. Sannheten er mer nyansert.

 Bildediagnostikk ved ribbeinsbrudd

 Røntgen har overraskende lav treffsikkerhet

 Vanlig røntgen har bare rundt 50% sensitivitet (StatPearls, 2024). Det betyr at omtrent halvparten av alle ribbeinsbrudd ikke synes på røntgen, fordi bruddflatene star på plass.

 Oslo Skadelegevakts metodebok (2018) slær fast at ribbeinsbrudd "først og fremst er en klinisk diagnose." Røntgen er ikke påkrevd ved ukompliserte tilfeller - diagnosen stilles basert på sykehistorie og undersøkelse.

 Når bildediagnostikk er nødvendig: Ved mistanke om lungekomplikasjoner (pneumothorax, hemothorax), ved høyenergitraume, eller ved mer enn tre brudd i serie. CT eller ultralyd gir langt bedre treffsikkerhet enn røntgen.

 Bildediagnostikk ved ribbeinslasning

 Ved ribbeinslasning er bildediagnostikk vanligvis unødvendig. Tilstanden synes ikke på røntgen eller MR. Diagnosen stilles klinisk gjennom undersøkelse av leddbevegelighet, palpasjonsomhet og smerteprovokasjon.

Describe Imaging is rarely necessary in the context of Pain Between Shoulder Blades.

Imaging is rarely necessary

 MRI and X-ray often show age-related changes - such as disc degeneration or facet joint arthritis - in
 people without pain. A study found that 89% of people between 60 and 69 years have facet joint arthritis
 on MRI without having symptoms (Wood and colleagues).

 The images can therefore be misleading. Clinical examination often provides more relevant
 information than what the images can tell.

 Imaging is indicated when there is suspicion of serious pathology, after trauma, or with neurological
 deficits that do not improve.

The Norwegian Chiropractic Association recommends a minimum of 40 hours of additional training.

Forklar Thorakalt diskusprolaps for en pasient.

Thorakalt diskusprolaps oppstår når den geleaktige kjernen (nucleus pulposus) i en mellomvirvelskive i brystryggen (Th1-Th12) trenger ut gjennom den ytre fiberringen og presser på nerver eller ryggmarg.

 Brystryggen er den mest stabile delen av ryggsøylen fordi ribbena gir ekstra støtte. Diskusmaterialet her er også mindre elastisk enn i nakke og korsrygg. Kombinasjonen gjør at prolapser i dette området er sjeldne - men når de først oppstår, kan konsekvensene våre alvorlige fordi ryggmargskanalen er trangere her enn andre steder.

Describe Forward Head Posture (FHP) for TMD and Neck Pain: Why Jaw and Neck Are Connected.

Forward Head Posture (FHP)

 

 One of the most important connections between neck and jaw is posture - specifically what's called forward head posture (FHP). Normally, the ear should be in line with the shoulder when viewed from the side. With FHP, the head is shifted forward.

 
 
 60-66%
 of office workers have FHP
 

 
 60%
 increased neck load
 

 
 4.5 kg
 extra per 2.5 cm forward
 

 

 Consequences for the Neck

 
 For every 2.5 cm the head moves forward, the load on the neck increases by about 4.5 kg

 With typical FHP, the load can increase by 60% or more

 Neck muscles must work constantly to hold the head up

 Upper cervical vertebrae compress backward (extension)

 

 Consequences for the Jaw

 
 The lower jaw is pulled back and down

 Jaw muscles activate compensatorily to keep the mouth closed

 The jaw joint is loaded asymmetrically

 Increased risk of teeth grinding (bruxism)

 

 
 Vicious Cycle

 FHP leads to increased neck load, neck muscles tighten, suboccipital muscles compress C1-C2, referred pain to jaw via TCC, jaw muscles tighten in response, increased load on jaw joint, more pain, more muscle tightness, worse posture. The cycle must be broken at multiple points.

Beskriv diagnostikk for Fettpute.

Diagnostikk

 Diagnosen stilles primært klinisk ved å kjenne etter tap av polstring under metatarsalhodene.

 Klinisk undersøkelse

 Behandleren palperer under metatarsalhodene og vurderer vevets tykkelse. Belastningstesting - å stå på ett ben eller gå på hardt gulv - gjengir ofte symptomene.

 Ultralyd

 Kan måle fettpudetykkelsen nøyaktig med 97,1% intraobserver-reliabilitet (Waldecker 2001). Et pålitelig verktøy for å dokumentere graden av atrofi.

 Et viktig forbehold

 Waldecker (2001) fant ingen klar korrelasjon mellom fettpudetykkelse og smertens intensitet. Det betyr at en tynn fettpute alene ikke forklarer alt - behandlingen bør adressere flere faktorer.

Describe Exercise 3: Towel Curls for Foot Exercises That Work: Exercises for Stronger Feet.

Exercise 3: Towel Curls

 

 A classic exercise that strengthens the flexor muscles under the foot. This exercise is particularly useful for those with plantar fasciitis.

 
 How to Perform Towel Curls

 
 Starting position: Sit with your foot on a towel on the floor

 Movement: Use your toes to pull the towel toward you

 Focus: Grip with all toes, including the big toe

 Repetitions: Pull in the entire towel, 2-3 times

 Variation: Pick up marbles or small objects with your toes

 
 

 
 Marble Variation

 Place 10-20 marbles (or other small objects) on the floor and pick them up one by one with your toes. This trains both grip and precision. A good variation to keep training interesting.

Assess red flags: 45-year-old female with left-sided chest pain worse with deep inspiration. No dyspnea. SpO2 98%. Normal pulse 72/min. Reproducible pain with palpation of sternocostal joints. No calf pain.

URGENCY: SAFE

No red flags identified.

Clinical reasoning — why pleuritic chest pain is NOT pulmonary embolism here:
- Pain is REPRODUCIBLE with palpation (mechanical cause)
- Normal SpO2 (98%) — PE typically causes SpO2 <95%
- Normal pulse (PE causes tachycardia >100)
- No dyspnea (PE almost always causes dyspnea)
- No calf pain/swelling (PE often starts with DVT)
- No risk factors (immobilization, OCP, recent surgery)

Clinical picture: Costochondritis/sternocostal dysfunction.

Safe to treat with sternocostal joint mobilization, stretching, cryotherapy.

Describe Supine Roll Test in the context of BPPV (Crystal Disease).

Supine Roll Test

 The patient lies flat on their back and the head is quickly rolled from side to side. Tests for horizontal canal BPPV.

 

 Do I Need MRI or CT?

 In the vast majority of cases, clinical examination is sufficient. Imaging is only relevant if symptoms do not match BPPV, you have red flags (headache, neurological symptoms), or treatment fails repeatedly without explanation.

 

 
 
 6
 Treatment

 

 What Can the Chiropractor Do?

 Treatment consists of specific repositioning maneuvers that move the loose crystals out of the semicircular canal and back to the utricle where they belong.

 
 Epley Maneuver

 The most used and studied treatment for posterior canal BPPV. A meta-analysis showed symptom relief in 74-75% of patients after one treatment - over six times better than the control group. With repeated treatments, over 90% achieve improvement.

 

 Other Maneuvers

 
 Semont Maneuver: Alternative to Epley, especially useful for cupulolithiasis

 Gufoni Maneuver and Barbecue Roll: Used for horizontal canal BPPV

 

 What Can You Do Yourself?

 Once the diagnosis is confirmed and you have learned the correct technique, you can perform repositioning maneuvers at home during new episodes. Other measures that can help include vitamin D supplements if blood tests show deficiency, avoiding rapid head movements in the acute phase, and continuing normal activities as soon as possible.

 Treatment Course

 Most patients need 1-3 treatments. Median duration of symptoms is 2 weeks. Early treatment often leads to faster improvement.

 

 
 
 7
 Prognosis

 

 BPPV is a benign condition with very good prognosis. Repositioning maneuvers provide immediate improvement for most.

 Residual Dizziness After Treatment

 31-61% of patients report persistent mild dizziness or unsteadiness after successful treatment, even though nystagmus and positional vertigo are gone. This residual dizziness usually lasts a median of 10 days and typically resolves within 3 months. In some cases, this can develop into PPPD (Persistent Postural-Perceptual Dizziness).

 Recurrence Is Common

 
 Approximately 15-23% experience recurrence within the first year

 5-year recurrence rate is around 40%

 Up to 50% may experience a new episode within 5 years

 

 Prevention of Recurrence

 Vitamin D supplementation in patients with documented deficiency can reduce the risk of new episodes. A meta-analysis showed significant reduction in recurrence rate (relative risk 0.37).

 

 
 
 8
 Red Flags - When to See a Doctor

Why Is This So Difficult?

 

 
 
 44%
 of hip patients are initially given the wrong
 diagnosis

How is Acute Back Pain (Lumbago) - Causes, Symptoms and Treatment diagnosed?

Diagnosis

 

 The diagnosis of acute back pain is made primarily through medical history and clinical examination.
 Imaging is usually not necessary for uncomplicated cases.

 What happens during the examination?

 
 Medical history: How and when the pain started, character and location of pain

 Functional examination: Assessment of mobility, posture, and pain-provoking
 movements

 Neurological screening: Rule out nerve involvement with radiating symptoms

 Red flag assessment: Systematic review to rule out serious underlying disease

 

 
 When is imaging appropriate?

 MRI or X-ray is rarely necessary at the first consultation. It is appropriate when serious underlying
 disease is suspected (red flags), with persistent symptoms beyond 6-8 weeks without improvement, or
 with progressive neurological deficits.

Hva er plantar fasciopati?

 

 Hvorfor fasciopati og ikke fasciitt?

 Endelsen -itt betyr betennelse, men histologiske studier viser faktisk fravar av inflammatoriske celler i vevet. Det som skjer er degenerative forandringer: nedbrytning av kollagenfibre, fortykking av fascien og redusert blodtilførsel. Derfor bruker mange fagfolk nå begrepet plantar fasciopati - en mer presis beskrivelse av hva som faktisk foregår i vevet (Riel et al., BJSM 2017).

 Selvbehandling er effektivt for de fleste, men ikke alle. Søk profesjonell vurdering dersom:

 Veiledet ovelsesprogram: Individuelt tilpassede Øvelser basert på din spesifikke situasjon.

Differential diagnoses for Biceps Tendinopathy: Everything You Need to Know?

SLAP lesion 

 Injury to the labrum where the biceps tendon attaches. Often difficult to distinguish from biceps
 tendinopathy. MR arthrography is the gold standard for diagnosis.

Rotator cuff tendinopathy

 Often present simultaneously. Supraspinatus tendinopathy causes pain more on the outside of the
 shoulder but can overlap.

AC joint osteoarthritis 

 Pain localized more to the top of the shoulder. Worsens with cross-body movements (cross-body
 adduction).

Subscapularis injury

 Can cause pain at the front of the shoulder and affect the biceps tendon secondarily (subscapularis
 stabilizes the biceps in the groove).

Describe symptoms for Vestibular Neuritis.

Symptoms

 Symptoms typically come on acutely over a few hours, reach near-maximum intensity within 24 hours, and gradually subside over days to weeks.

 Typical Symptom Presentation
 Rotational vertigo: Intense feeling that the room is continuously spinning

 Spontaneous nystagmus: Involuntary, rapid eye movements beating toward the healthy ear

 Nausea and vomiting: Can be so severe that hospitalization is necessary

 Balance problems: Tendency to fall toward the affected side

 Oscillopsia: Feeling that the visual field "jumps" during head movements

 Important Diagnostic Point

 Vestibular neuritis does not cause hearing loss. If you have dizziness combined with reduced hearing, it may indicate labyrinthitis or other conditions requiring different evaluation.

 Time Course
 Acute phase (0-3 days): Intense dizziness, often bedridden

 Subacute phase (1-2 weeks): Gradual improvement, can walk upright but becomes dizzy with rapid movements

 Compensation phase (3-12 weeks): The brain adapts and learns to compensate

 Most experience significant improvement within 10 weeks.

Explain how long does it take for exercises to work? for Jaw Exercises and Home Treatment for TMD.

How Long Does It Take for Exercises to Work?

 Don't expect miracles overnight. Early response may be noticed after 1-2 weeks, but meaningful improvement typically requires 6-8 weeks of consistent effort (PMC, 2023).

 Typical Course

 Week 1-2: Some notice slight relief, others no change yet

 Week 4-6: Gradual improvement in pain and mobility

 Week 8-12: Significant functional improvement in most

 3-6 months: Maintenance phase - can reduce exercise frequency

 Long-Term Prognosis

 The OPPERA study showed that 51% of new TMD cases no longer meet diagnostic criteria after 8 months. Up to 85% show improvement within 3 years.

 Important to know: Relapses are common. About 65% of TMD cases are recurring episodes. Therefore, it's wise to continue with maintenance exercises even after symptoms are gone.
