Beskriv Ofte stilte spørsmål for Vondt i Hoften? - Komplett guide.

Ofte stilte spørsmål

 

 
 Er det farlig at det "knekker" eller "klikker" i hoften?

 Som regel ikke. "Snapping hip" er veldig vanlig - rammer 5-10% av befolkningen - og er sjelden farlig så lenge det ikke gjør vondt. Lyden skyldes oftest en sene som glir over en beinkant. Hos ballett-dansere er forekomsten opptil 90%. Bekymringsfullt blir det først hvis klikkingen ledsages av smerte, lasing, eller følelse av at hoften "gir etter".

 

 
 Hjelper det å toye hoften?

 Vårforsiktig. Ved seneproblemer på utsiden av hoften (GTPS) eller høyt på baksiden av læret (proksimal hamstring), kan aggressiv tøying faktisk gjøre vondt verre. Tøying presser senen mot benet og Øker kompresjonen. Fokuser heller på styrketrening og bevegelighet innenfor smertegrensen.

 

 
 Hjelper kortison?

 Kortvarig lindring ja, men langtidseffekten er dårlig. Trening gir bedre resultater etter 1 Ør. Les mer om behandling.

 

 
 Kan jeg trene med hoftesmerter?

 Ja, og det bør du! Forskning viser at trening er mer effektivt enn passiv behandling for de fleste hofte- og bekkensmerter. Men du må trene smart: unnga aktiviteter som gir sterk smerte, og start med Øvelser som ikke belaster leddet i ytterposisjoner. En kiropraktor eller fysioterapeut kan veilede deg til riktige Øvelser.

 

 
 Trenger jeg MR eller røntgen?

 Ofte ikke med det første. En klinisk undersøkelse gir vanligvis nok informasjon. Bildediagnostikk er aktuelt hvis du ikke blir bedre som forventet. Les om MR-fellen.

 

 
 Hvor lenge tar ...

Differensialdiagnoser ved Hodepine på toppen av hodet?

Spenningshodepine

 Vanligst - 46% livstid 

 Spenningshodepine er den desidert vanligste årsaken til hodepine på toppen av hodet. Livstidsprevalensen er 46% globalt, og danske studier viser opptil 78%. Kvinner rammes dobbelt så ofte som menn.

 Typisk presentasjon er bilateral, pressende eller strammende smerte - ofte beskrevet som et "band rundt hodet" som kan fokuseres på toppen. Smerten er mild til moderat og forverres ikke av fysisk aktivitet.

 Risikofaktorer: Stress, dårlig søvn, langvarig skjermarbeid og statiske arbeidsstillinger.

Triggerpunkter i nakkemuskulatur

 Referert smerte 

 Muskler i nakken kan referere smerte til toppen av hodet gjennom et fenomen kalt "referred pain". Les mer om triggerpunkter og hodepine .

 Splenius capitis er den primære muskelen som sender smerte spesifikt til issen. Triggerpunkter i denne muskelen - som ligger omtrent ved C3-niva - skaper en karakteristisk smertefølelse i en 3-5 cm sone midt på toppen av hodet. Pasienter beskriver ofte dette som "intern hodesmerte" eller "trykk på issen".

 Suboccipitale muskler (de små musklene helt overst i nakken) finnes å ha aktive triggerpunkter hos 65% av pasienter med kronisk spenningshodepine. Disse musklene har en direkte anatomisk forbindelse til hjernehinnene.

Cervikogen hodepine

 2,5-4,1% av befolkningen 

 Cervikogen hodepine skyldes dysfunksjon i øvre nakkevirvler (C1-C3) og omliggende strukturer. Den norske Vaga-studien fant 4,1% prevalens.

 Denne typen hodepine starter typisk i nakken og stråler oppover mot toppen av hodet på en side. Smerten forverres av nakkebevegelser og vedvarende holdninger.

Occipitalnevralgi

 Sjelden 

 Occipitalnevralgi gir skarp, skytende smerte fra bakhodet som kan stråle til toppen av hodet. Smerten følger forløpet til occipitalnerven og er ofte ensidig med perioder av intense "lyn"-lignende smerter.

Differential diagnoses for Overtraining and Overuse?

Training diary

 The most important tool. Log training load (volume, intensity, RPE), sleep quality, energy level, mood, and pain. Over time, this reveals trends and warning signs. Apps like TrainingPeaks, Polar Flow, or a simple spreadsheet work well.

Heart rate variability (HRV)

 HRV measures the variation between heartbeats and reflects the balance of the autonomic nervous system. A 2024 systematic review shows that a sustained drop in HRV over several days may indicate insufficient recovery. Measure HRV consistently – same time, same position, preferably in the morning before getting up.

Orthostatic test (resting test)

 Measure your heart rate lying down for 10 minutes, stand up and measure again after 1 minute. An abnormal response (exaggerated heart rate increase or lack of response) may indicate autonomic dysfunction from overtraining. Several heart rate monitors offer this test automatically.

Blood tests

 Primarily to rule out other conditions: blood count (anemia), ferritin (iron stores), CRP (inflammation), TSH/free T4 (thyroid function), cortisol, testosterone, vitamin D. Creatine kinase (CK) may be elevated with muscle damage. None of these are diagnostic for OTS alone, but the pattern can support the diagnosis.

Differential diagnoses for Why Does My Shoulder Click? Causes and When to Worry?

Cavitation (gas bubbles)

 Harmless 

 The same process as when you crack your knuckles. Gas bubbles in the synovial fluid are released and
 make a "pop" sound. This doesn't damage the joint and requires no treatment.

Tendons sliding over bone

 Harmless 

 The shoulder has many tendons that pass over bony prominences. During certain movements, these can
 "snap" or slide over the bone and make a sound. Common and normal.

Ligament tension

 Harmless 

 Ligaments can suddenly tighten during movement and make a snapping sound. Especially common in people
 with increased joint mobility (hypermobility).

Muscle tightness

 Harmless 

 Tight muscles around the shoulder can affect how tendons and other structures move, which can lead to
 temporary clicking. Often improves with stretching and activity.

Beskriv Hvorfor får man hodepine etter nakkesleng? for Hodepine Etter Nakkesleng - Whiplash og Hodepine.

Hvorfor får man hodepine etter nakkesleng?

 

 Vanligste Årsaker - fra mest til minst vanlig

 
 1. Fasettleddskader (ca. 60% av kroniske tilfeller)

 Studier med diagnostiske blokader viser at fasettleddene i nakken er hovedkilden til smerter hos flertallet med kronisk nakkesleng (Lord & Barnsley, Spine 1996). De hyppigst affiserte nivåene er C2-C3 (36%) og C5-C6 (35%).

 

 
 2. Muskel- og ligamentskader

 De dype nakkemusklene og ligamentene - spesielt rundt Øvre nakkeledd (C1-C2) - får ofte mikroskader. MR-studier har vist fettinfiltrasjon i disse musklene etter whiplash.

 

 
 3. Trigeminocervikal konvergens

 Smertenerver fra nakken (C1-C3) måter trigeminusnerven i hjernestammen. Dette forklarer hvorfor nakkeskade gir hodepine - smertesignaler fra nakken "feiltolkes" som hodepine.

 

 
 4. Sentral sensitivisering

 Ved kronisk nakkesleng kan nervesystemet bli overfålsomt. Systematiske oversikter bekrefter at kronisk WAD involverer sentral sensitivisering med lavere smerteterskler og førsterket smerteoppfattelse (Van Oosterwijck et al., 2013).

Explain prognosis - what happens long term? for Spinal Stenosis.

Prognosis - What Happens Long Term?

 Here I have good news: The natural course of spinal stenosis is often more favorable than many think.

 Without Treatment (JAMA Review 2022)

 About 33% report spontaneous improvement, 50% remain stable, and 10-20% experience worsening over 3
 years.

 Surgery vs Conservative Treatment

 The large SPORT study showed that surgery had somewhat better results in the short term, but
 after 6-8 years there was no significant difference between surgical and conservative
 treatment.

 Recurrence: It's important to be realistic - this is a condition related to aging of
 the spine, and recurrence can occur. Regular maintenance exercise is important to maintain function.

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Scheuermann's Disease.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 Can Scheuermann's disease be cured?

 The structural change in the vertebrae is permanent. In adolescents, correct treatment
 (brace + exercise) can slow or stop progression. In adults, treatment focuses on
 symptoms and function, not structure.

 

 
 Is Scheuermann's the same as poor posture?

 No. Scheuermann's is a structural condition where the vertebrae themselves are shaped
 differently. Postural kyphosis is due to muscular habits and can be corrected actively.
 A person with Scheuermann's cannot "straighten up" in the same way.

 

 
 Will I always have pain?

 Not necessarily. As many as 25% of adults with Scheuermann's report no back pain. With
 proper exercise and lifestyle adaptation, many live well with the condition.

 

 
 Can I exercise normally?

 Yes, most forms of exercise are both safe and recommended. Swimming, strength training,
 running and yoga are all good alternatives. Be careful with very heavy lifting with
 axial loading (like heavy squats and deadlifts) if you have symptoms.

 

 
 Will my children inherit the condition?

 There is a significant genetic component (74% heritability), so children have increased
 risk. Be aware of posture changes in puberty and seek assessment if concerned.

 

 
 Do I need X-ray or MRI?

 X-ray confirms diagnosis and measures curve (Cobb angle). MRI is rarely necessary unless
 there is suspicion of other conditions or neurological symptoms.

 

 
 Does it get worse with age?

 The ...

Describe causes and risk factors for SLAP Lesion: Everything You Need to Know.

Causes and risk factors

 SLAP lesions can occur in several ways
 Acute injury

 Fall on outstretched arm: Compression forces push the upper arm bone up against the
 labrum

 Direct trauma: Blow to the shoulder

 Sudden pull: Heavy lifting or jerking of the arm

 Overload (most common)

 Repetitive overhead activity

 Main cause 

 Throwing movements and overhead sports expose the biceps attachment to repeated pulling forces. Over
 time, this can lead to SLAP lesion. Common in
 Handball players (see thrower's shoulder )

 Volleyball players

 Baseball pitchers

 Swimmers

 Tennis players

 Risk factors

 Overhead sports, especially throwing sports

 Age 20-40 years for traumatic lesions

 Age over 40 for degenerative changes (type I)

 Glenohumeral internal rotation deficit (GIRD)

 Weak scapula control

 Previous shoulder instability

 Important perspective

 Many have SLAP lesions on MRI without symptoms. A study found that up to 55% of asymptomatic
 shoulders in people over 45 years had labrum changes. This means an MRI finding does not necessarily
 explain your pain.

Describe Phase 1: Relaxation (Start Here) for Jaw Exercises at Home: Complete Exercise Program for TMD.

Phase 1: Relaxation (Start Here)

 

 1. Breathing and Jaw Relaxation

 
 Sit or lie comfortably

 Close your eyes and breathe slowly through your nose

 On exhale: Let the jaw "fall" down slightly (lips still closed)

 Feel the jaw muscles relax more with each exhale

 5-10 breaths, repeat several times daily

 

 2. Resting Position Training

 
 Say the letter "N" softly

 Notice where your tongue is - against the palate behind the front teeth

 Let the teeth be separated by 2-3 mm

 Lips relaxed together

 This is the jaw's ideal resting position

 
 Tip: Set phone alarms to check your jaw position throughout the day.

 3. Progressive Muscle Relaxation for the Jaw

 
 Clench your teeth lightly for 5 seconds

 Relax completely for 10 seconds

 Notice the difference between tension and relaxation

 Repeat 5 times

 
 NB: Don't use maximum strength - only light tension!

Describe What Happens in the Ear? for Meniere's Disease.

What Happens in the Ear?

 

 The underlying mechanism is believed to be endolymphatic hydrops - an accumulation of fluid (endolymph) in the inner ear. The inner ear consists of a labyrinth system filled with fluid that must have the right pressure and chemical composition to function normally.

 In Meniere's disease, too much fluid is produced, or drainage does not work properly. This causes the pressure to rise. At high pressure, a thin membrane (Reissner's membrane) can rupture, and fluids with different chemical compositions mix. This disrupts the signals to the brain and triggers the characteristic attack.

 
 Genetic Component

 Approximately 7-10% of patients with Meniere's disease have a family history of the condition.

Handårsaker

 Karpaltunnelsyndrom

 Den vanligste årsaken til nummenhet i fingrene. Medianusnerven blir klemt i karpaltunnelen - en trang passasje i handleddet.

 Kjennetegn på karpaltunnelsyndrom

 Fingre påvirket: Tommel, pekefinger, langfinger, og halve ringfinger

 Verre om natten: Mange vakner av nummenhet og må riste på handen

 Lindres ved risting: å riste på handen gir ofte kortvarig lindring

 Ingen nakkesmerte: Symptomene er lokalisert til hand og underarm

 Risikofaktorer: Graviditet, diabetes, hypothyreose, repetitivt arbeid

 Ulnarisnerveaffeksjon (Cubitaltunnelsyndrom)

 Kjennetegn på ulnarispåvirkning

 Fingre påvirket: Lillefinger og halve ringfinger (ulnare halvdel)

 Albueposisjon: Ofte verre ved bøyning av albuen eller ved å hvile på albuen

 Innsiden av handen: Kan gi svakhet i de små handmusklene

 "Klofingre": Ved alvorlige tilfeller kan fingrene få kloliknende stilling

 Thoracic Outlet Syndrome (TOS) 

 Nervene og blodarene til armen kan bli klemt i området mellom nakkebasis og armhulen.

 Nummenhet og prikking i hele handen eller flere fingre

 Kan gi kuldefølelse og fargeforandringer i handen

 Ofte forbundet med dårlig holdning eller ekstra nakkeribben

Describe diagnosis for Sciatica: Everything You Need to Know.

Diagnosis

 Clinical examination

 Diagnosis is primarily based on medical history and clinical examination. A thorough neurological
 examination can often locate which level in the spine is affected.

 Straight leg raise test is the most predictive test for identifying candidates for
 surgery. The test is positive when it reproduces the patient's pain with a leg raise under 45 degrees with
 radiation below the knee (StatPearls, 2023).

 Imaging

 MRI or CT is not routinely recommended . Danish national guidelines discourage routine
 imaging for new-onset sciatica (European Spine Journal, 2018).

 Important to understand

 Imaging often shows normal findings like wear and degenerative changes that don't explain the pain.
 Studies show that up to 20-80% of symptom-free people have MRI findings like disc bulging, degeneration
 or protrusion (StatPearls, 2023).

 Imaging is indicated for
 Suspicion of serious pathology ( red flags )

 Persistent symptoms after 6-8 weeks of conservative treatment

 When considering surgery

Gi en strukturert klinisk oversikt over Er det farlig at nakken knaser?.

Hva er krepitasjon?: Krepitasjon er det medisinske begrepet for lyder som oppstår i ledd og bløtvev ved bevegelse. I nakken kan dette høres som knasing, knepping, klikking eller knirking. Lydene kan variere fra et enkelt "klikk" til en serie med knasende lyder.

Hvorfor knaser nakken?: Det finnes flere forklaringer på hvorfor nakken lager lyd. De fleste er helt ufarlige og krever ingen behandling.

Når er det ufarlig?: I de aller fleste tilfeller er knasing i nakken helt ufarlig. Her er tegn på at du ikke trenger å bekymre deg
Bør jeg knekke nakken selv?: Mange opplever en midlertidig lettelse når de knekker nakken selv. Men det er viktig å skille mellom tilfeldig knasing ved bevegelse og aktivt å manipulere nakken for å få den til å knekke.

Når bør du oppsøke hjelp?: Selv om knasing vanligvis er ufarlig, er det noen situasjoner der du bør la deg undersøke
Behandling og forebygging: Hvis knasingen er ufarlig og ikke gir plager, trengs ingen behandling. Men hvis du opplever stivhet eller ubehag sammen med lydene, kan følgende hjelpe
Ofte stilte spørsmål: Nei, vanligvis ikke. Krepitasjon (knasing) i nakken er svært vanlig og skyldes ofte at gassbobler frigjøres fra leddene, sener glir over bein, eller normale aldersforandringer. Det er sjelden tegn på noe alvorlig.

Beskriv symptomer og kjennetegn for Vestibulær Hypofunksjon: Den Komplette Guiden.

Symptomer

 

 Symptomer ved ensidig hypofunksjon

 
 
 
 Symptom
 Forekomst
 
 
 
 
 Kronisk svimmelhet
 98%
 
 
 Ubalanse/ustøhet
 81%
 
 
 Forverring ved hodebevegelser
 75%
 
 
 Oscillopsi (ustabilt syn ved bevegelse)
 22-70%
 
 
 Tretthet/utmattelse
 68%
 
 
 

 Symptomer ved tosidig hypofunksjon

 Tosidig hypofunksjon gir en karakteristisk symptomtriade:

 
 1. Ustohet ved gange og staing

 Hovedplagen, særlig på ujevnt underlag, i morket eller ved hodebevegelser. Mange beskriver at de foler seg som om de "går på en bat".

 

 
 2. Oscillopsi - når verden hopper

 Ofte det mest plagsomme symptomet. Synsbildet "hopper" ved hodebevegelser. Ca. 70% opplever dette.

 

 
 3. Symptomfritt i hvile

 Symptomene er borte når du sitter eller ligger stille. Dette skiller tosidig hypofunksjon fra andre Årsaker.

 

 
 4. Ingen roterende svimmelhet

 Sjelden klassisk vertigo fordi begge sider er like svake - det er ingen ubalanse som skaper rotasjonsfølelsen.

 

 
 Røde flagg - når du må søke lege umiddelbart

 Ring 113 eller oppsøk legevakt umiddelbart ved:

 
 Akutt svimmelhet kombinert med hodepine, nakkesmerter eller nylig traume

 Talevansker, svelgevansker eller uklart sprak

 Lammelser, nummenhet eller svakhet i ansikt, arm eller ben

 Dobbeltsyn eller synsfeltutfall

 Endret bevissthet eller forvirring

 
 Opptil 25% av akutte svimmelhetstilfeller på legevakt kan skyldes slag i bakre hjernekrets.

Beskriv diagnostikk for POTS og Ortostatisk Svimmelhet.

Diagnostikk

 Diagnosekriterier (Heart Rhythm Society 2015)

 For å fa diagnosen POTS må du oppfylle
 Pulsokning på >=30 slag/min (>=40 for 12-19 år) innen 10 minutter etter å ha reist deg

 Eller puls over 120 slag/min ved standing

 Fraver av ortostatisk hypotensjon (blodtrykksfall >=20 mmHg)

 Symptomer har vart i mer enn 3 måneder

 Ingen annen tilstand som forklarer symptomene

 Aktiv statest (kan gjøres på klinikk)

 En enkel test: Du ligger flatt i 5-10 minutter, puls og blodtrykk males, du reiser deg og star rolig, og malinger gjøres etter 1, 3, 5 og 10 minutter. Pulsokning >=30 uten blodtrykksfall tyder på POTS.

 Røde flagg - søk lege umiddelbart ved
 Brystsmerter eller trykk i brystet

 Alvorlig kortpustethet

 Gjentatte besvimelser

 Uregelmessig hjerterytme

 Symptomer som forverres raskt

 Nevrologiske symptomer (synstap, talevansker, ensidig svakhet)

 POTS i seg selv er ikke farlig, men symptomene kan ligne andre tilstander som krever akutt behandling.

Hva sier ny forskning om behandling?

 

 Slutt på "cocoon"-tilnærmingen

 Amsterdam Consensus Statement fra 2023 - den mest omfattende gjennomgangen av hjernerystelsesforskning noensinne (78 000 studier vurdert) - snur opp ned på gammel praksis.

 
 Tidligere vs. ny anbefaling

 Tidligere anbefaling: Total hvile fra all fysisk og kognitiv aktivitet til symptomfrihet.

 Ny anbefaling: 24-48 timer med relativ hvile, deretter gradvis oppstart av lett aerob aktivitet. Streng hvile ("cocooning") er ikke gunstig og kan faktisk forlenge bedringen.

 

 
 En randomisert studie med 103 ungdommer viste at de som startet kontrollert trening tidlig ble friske på median 13 dager, mot 17 dager for gruppen som bare hvilte. Forlenget bedring over 30 dager rammet bare 4% i treningsgruppen mot 14% i hvilegruppen.

Skriv vurderingsdelen av et SOAP-notat for Krystallsyke (BPPV).

Diagnostikk

 

 Diagnosen stilles primert gjennom sykehistorie og klinisk undersøkelse. De viktigste testene er:

 
 Dix-Hallpike-testen

 Pasienten sitter på benken med hodet dreid 45 grader mot den mistenkte siden, legges raskt bakover til hodet henger 20 grader under horisontalplanet. Ved bakre kanal BPPV ses oppslaende, roterende nystagmus etter noen sekunders forsinkelse.

 

 
 Supine roll-test

 Pasienten ligger flatt på ryggen og hodet rulles raskt fra side til side. Tester for horisontal kanal BPPV.

 

 Trenger jeg MR eller CT?

 I de aller fleste tilfeller er klinisk undersøkelse

Provide a structured clinical overview of Trigger Points in Arm and Forearm.

What are trigger points?: Trigger points are hypersensitive areas in muscle fibers - often described as "knots" or "tightness."
 When you press on a trigger point, it causes characteristic pain, and often also referred
 pain - pain that radiates to other areas.

Why do trigger points develop?: Trigger points develop when muscle fibers become overloaded or damaged. The most common causes in arm and
 forearm
Referred pain - pain in the wrong place: The most confusing thing about trigger points is referred pain : pain is felt in a
 completely different place from where the problem is. This explains why many get the wrong diagnosis.

Symptoms of trigger points: How to recognize trigger points in arm and forearm
Treatment of trigger points: Trigger points respond well to manual treatment. The most important methods
What can you do yourself?: You can treat many trigger points yourself with simple techniques

Differential diagnoses for Thumb Arthritis (CMC?

Genetics (39-65% hereditary)

 Heredity is by far the most important factor. If your mother has thumb arthritis, your risk is
 significantly increased.

Gender

 Women are affected 2-3 times more often than men. Hormones and joint laxity play a role.

Age

 Most common after 50, but X-ray findings can be found as early as the 40s.

Load

 Heavy manual work and repetitive gripping movements over time increase risk somewhat. This is similar
 to the causation pattern for mouse arm and other overuse conditions in the arm .

Beskriv Hva er svimmelhet? for Svimmelhet - Komplett guide.

Hva er svimmelhet?

 

 Svimmelhet er ikke en ting. Det er et paraplybegrep som dekker flere ulike opplevelser:

 
 Tre typer svimmelhet

 
 Vertigo: Følelsen av at du eller omgivelsene roterer. Rommet spinner, eller du føler at du snurrer rundt selv om du star stille. Dette skyldes nesten alltid forstyrrelser i balanseorganet.

 Uståhet: Beskrives ofte som en gyngende eller vuggende følelse - som å stå på et bøtdekk. Du føler deg ikke helt stabil på beina.

 Ørhet: En diffus følelse av å våre "tØkete" i hodet. Noen beskriver det som at de nesten skal besvime.

 
 

 Hvordan balansen fungerer

 Tre systemer sender kontinuerlig informasjon til hjernen:

 
 
 👂

 Balanseorganet

 I det indre Øret - registrerer hodets bevegelser og posisjon

 

 
 👁

 Øynene

 Forteller hjernen hvor du befinner deg i forhold til omgivelsene

 

 
 🦶

 Kroppssansen

 Sensorer i muskler, sener og ledd gir beskjed om kroppens stilling

 

 

 Når alle tre systemene sender samsvarende signaler, føler du deg stabil. Når ett system sender feil informasjon - eller systemene sender motstridende signaler - oppstar svimmelhet.

Hva forårsaker SLAP-lesjon: Alt du trenger å vite?

Årsaker og risikofaktorer

 

 SLAP-lesjoner kan oppstå på flere mater:

 Akutt skade

 
 Fall på utstrakt arm: Kompresjonskrefter presser overarmshodet opp mot labrum

 Direkte traume: Slag mot skulderen

 Plutselig drag: Tungt løft eller rykk i armen

 

 Overbelastning (vanligst)

 
 
 Repeterende overhead-aktivitet

 HovedÅrsak
 

 Kastebevegelser og overhead-idretter utsetter bicepsfestet for gjentatte drag-krefter. Over tid kan dette fore til SLAP-lesjon. Vanlig hos:

 
 Handballspillere (se kasterskulder)

 Volleyballspillere

 Baseball-kastere

 Svommere

 Tennissillere

 
 

 Risikofaktorer

 
 Overhead-idretter, særlig kasteidretter

 Alder 20-40 Ør for traumatiske lesjoner

 Alder over 40 for degenerative forandringer (type I)

 Glenohumeral innadrotasjonsunderskudd (GIRD)

 Svak scapula-kontroll

 Tidligere skulderinstabilitet

 

 
 Viktig perspektiv

 Mange har SLAP-lesjoner på MR uten symptomer. En studie fant at opptil 55% av asymptomatiske skulder hos personer over 45 Ør hadde labrum-forandringer. Dette betyr at et MR-funn ikke nødvendigvis forklarer smerten din.

Describe causes and risk factors for SI Joint Problems and Pelvic Dysfunction.

Causes and Risk Factors

 Common Causes

 Asymmetric loading - for example, standing on one leg for long periods

 Sudden movement - misstep, lifting with twisting

 Pregnancy - hormones make the ligaments more elastic

 Fall on the buttocks - direct trauma to the pelvis

 Prolonged sitting - especially on hard surfaces

 Leg length difference - creates uneven loading

 Risk Factors

 Female sex - 3 times higher risk

 Previous pregnancy - especially multiple births

 Lumbar fusion - surgery that increases load on the SI joint

 Leg length difference - over 5mm

 Sports with rotation - golf, tennis, hockey

 Heavy physical work - especially with lifting and twisting

 Why are women affected more often?

 Women's SI joints are more mobile due to the hormones estrogen and relaxin. During pregnancy, mobility
 increases further to prepare the body for childbirth. This increased mobility can lead to irritation and
 pain.

Describe causes and risk factors for Tarsal Tunnel Syndrome.

Causes and Risk Factors

 Biomechanical factors - most common

 Flat feet (pes planus) and overpronation increase tension on the nerve. Every time the foot rolls inward, the structures in the tunnel tighten. Over time, this can irritate the nerve. See also tibialis posterior tendinopathy and overpronation .

 Other causes

 Ganglion cysts: The most common identifiable cause of tarsal tunnel syndrome

 Ankle injuries: Sprains, fractures or scar tissue after surgery can narrow the tunnel

 Vascular causes: Recent 2025 research shows varicose veins in the tunnel are a more commonly overlooked cause than previously thought

 Systemic conditions: Diabetes, hypothyroidism and rheumatic conditions increase the risk

 Idiopathic (20-40%): No specific cause can be identified

Differential diagnoses for Superior Canal Dehiscence Syndrome?

Meniere's Disease 

 Also causes hearing loss and dizziness, but attacks come spontaneously and last 20 minutes to several hours. In SCDS, symptoms are temporally related to specific sound or pressure triggers.

BPPV (Crystal Disease) 

 Triggered by head movements and causes brief spinning dizziness that diminishes with repeated movements. SCDS is triggered by sound and pressure, not head position.

Otosclerosis

 Also causes hearing loss in low frequencies, but in otosclerosis the stapedius reflex is absent - in SCDS it is normal. This difference is important because stapedectomy (surgery for otosclerosis) is contraindicated in SCDS.

Beskriv Hva er vestibulær migrene? for Vestibulær Migrene: Når Svimmelheten Tar Over Livet.

Hva er vestibulær migrene?

 

 Vestibulær migrene er en nevrologisk tilstand der migrenemekanismene i hjernen påvirker balansesentrene i hjernestammen og lillehjernen. I motsetning til hva mange tror, trenger du ikke ha hodepine under et anfall. Faktisk opplever kun rundt 25% av pasientene hodepine samtidig med svimmelheten.

 Tilstanden rammer 1-3% av befolkningen og er langt vanligere enn Menieres sykdom, som mange feilaktig diagnostiseres med. I spesialiserte svimmelhetsklinikker utgjør vestibulær migrene opptil 25% av alle nyhenviste pasienter. Kvinner rammes oftere enn menn, med et forhold på omtrent 3-5:1.

 
 
 1-3%
 av befolkningen
 

 
 25%
 av svimmelhetsklinikk-pasienter
 

 
 7-8 Ør
 gjennomsnittlig tid til diagnose
 

 

 
 Hvorfor blir tilstanden så ofte oversett?

 Hodepine og svimmelhet opptrer sjelden samtidig. Pasienten kan ha hatt migrene i ungdommen som "forsvant," for så å utvikle uforklarlig svimmelhet 10-20 Ør senere. I en amerikansk undersøkelse var det bare 10% av pasientene som oppfylte kriteriene for vestibulær migrene som hadde fått beskjed om at migrene var Årsaken.

Describe symptoms of c5-c6 disc herniation for C5.

Symptoms of C5-C6 Disc Herniation

 The symptoms of C5-C6 disc herniation are quite specific and follow the distribution of the C6 nerve.
 They can vary in intensity from mild numbness to significant pain and weakness.

 Typical C6 Symptoms

 Pain: Radiates from the neck, out to the shoulder, down the outer upper arm to
 the thumb and index finger

 Numbness /tingling: Thumb and index finger,
 sometimes the middle finger

 Weakness: Difficulty bending the elbow (biceps) or extending the wrist

 Reflex change: Reduced brachioradialis reflex

 Pain Provocation

 Symptoms typically worsen with
 Turning the head toward the affected side

 Bending the neck backward (extension)

 Coughing or sneezing

 Pressing down on the head (Spurling's test)

 Bakody's Sign - Relief from Raising the Arm

 A characteristic finding in cervical radiculopathy is that pain is relieved when you place your hand
 on your head. This reduces tension on the nerve root and is a useful diagnostic sign.

 Pain Pattern Throughout the Day

 With cervical radiculopathy, pain is often worst at night and early morning. This is because the neck
 remains in a static position for a long time, and any swelling around the nerve has time to accumulate.

Differensialdiagnoser ved Hodepine i tinningen?

Spenningshodepine

 Vanligst - 26-33% 

 Spenningshodepine er den hyppigste årsaken til tinningssmerte. Smerten beskrives typisk som et pressende band rundt hodet, ofte bilateralt. Den topper seg i alderen 30-39 år og er noe vanligere hos kvinner.

 Utløsende faktorer: Stress, dårlig søvn, langvarig skjermarbeid og muskulære spenninger i nakke og skuldre. Triggerpunkter i øvre trapezius kan gi referert smerte i et karakteristisk "rams horn"-mønster.

Migrene

 11-15% 

 Migrene har en årlig befolkningsprevalens på 11-15% (HUNT-studiene). Kvinner rammes omtrent tre ganger så ofte som menn. Migrenesmerte er typisk pulserende og ofte ensidig, gjerne lokalisert til tinningen.

 Migrene skiller seg fra spenningshodepine ved at den ofte ledsages av kvalme, lys- og lydfølsomhet, og forverres ved fysisk aktivitet. Mange opplever også forvarsel (aura) med synsforstyrrelser for hodepinen. Noen utvikler også vestibulær migrene med episodisk vertigo.

Kjeveleddsplager (TMD)

 5-10% 

 Temporomandibulære dysfunksjoner (TMD) gir klinisk signifikante symptomer hos 5-10% av befolkningen. Kvinner rammes 2-4 ganger oftere enn menn, med høyest forekomst i alderen 20-40 år.

 Forholdet mellom TMD og hodepine er toveis: omtrent 62% av TMD-pasienter rapporterer hodepine, og 59% av hodepinepasienter har tegn på TMD-involvering.

 Typiske symptomer: Kjevesmerter, klikkelyder ved gaping, begrenset gapeevne, og hodepine som forverres ved tygging eller kjevebruk.

Cervikogen hodepine

 0,4-4% 

 Cervikogen hodepine utgår fra strukturer i nakken og refererer smerte til hodet, inkludert tinningen. Forekomsten i befolkningen er 0,4-4%, men utgjør 15-20% av kroniske cefalalgi-tilfeller i tertiærklinisk praksis.

 Kjennetegn: Ensidig hodepine som starter i nakken, redusert nakkebevegelse, og forverring ved bestemte nakkeposisjoner. Hodepinen bytter vanligvis ikke side.

Describe Self-Help in the context of Occipital Neuralgia.

Self-Help

 
 Heat treatment: Heat pack on the neck can loosen muscles

 Ergonomics: Adjust your workstation to avoid forward head posture

 Stretching: Gentle stretching of neck muscles

 Avoid triggers: Identify and avoid positions/activities that trigger pain

 
 

 Medication Treatment

 If conservative treatment is insufficient, a doctor may consider:

 
 NSAIDs: Ibuprofen or similar for mild to moderate pain

 Neuropathic pain medications: Gabapentin, pregabalin, or amitriptyline

 Muscle relaxants: For significant muscle spasm

 
 With frequent use of painkillers (more than 10-15 days per month), be aware of the risk of medication overuse headache.

 Invasive Treatments

 For refractory cases, the following may be considered by a specialist:

 
 Occipital nerve block: Injection of local anesthetic +/- corticosteroid

 Botulinum toxin: Can reduce muscle tension and nerve activity

 Pulsed radiofrequency treatment

 Occipital nerve stimulator: For chronic, refractory cases

 
 

 
 
 
 7
 Prognosis

 

 The prognosis for occipital neuralgia varies depending on the underlying cause:

 
 Muscle-related: Often good prognosis with manual treatment and self-help

 Traumatic: May take longer, but often improves over months

 Idiopathic: Variable course - some experience spontaneous improvement, others develop chronic daily headache

 

 
 Many Get Better

 Most people with occipital neuralgia experience significant improvement with proper treatment. Conservative measures such as manual treatment, self-help, and medications often help. For those who don't respond, more invasive alternatives exist.

Symptoms

 Symptoms of AC joint osteoarthritis are often characteristic and localized
 Typical Symptoms

 Localized pain: On top of the shoulder, often pinpointable

 Provocation by movements: Reaching across to opposite shoulder (cross-body)

 Pain with overhead: Especially at end range of movement

 Crepitus: Grinding or clicking from the joint

 Activities That Typically Provoke

 Bench press and shoulder press

 Dips and push-ups

 Putting on a jacket

 Reaching up to cabinets

 Sleeping on affected side

 Distinguishing from Other Conditions

 AC joint pain can resemble other shoulder conditions but has some distinctive features
 Signs That Point to the AC Joint

 Pain localized directly on top of the shoulder

 Positive cross-body adduction test

 Tenderness on direct palpation over the AC joint

 Pain at end range of overhead movement

 Pain relief with injection into the AC joint

 Hva kan kiropraktoren gjøre?

 Hva kan du gjøre selv?

 
 Hjemmetiltak

 
 Varme eller kulde: Varm klut på tyggemusklene kan lindre spenninger

 Unngå ekstrem gaping: Ver forsiktig ved store hamburgere, langvarig tannlegebesok

 Slapp av i kjeven: "Leppene sammen, tennene fra hverandre"

 Stresshandtering: AvspenningsØvelser og god søvn hjelper betydelig

 Forsiktige toyninger: Rolige gapebevegelser og sideveis bevegelser

 
 

 Behandlingsforløp

 Norske retningslinjer anbefaler en trinnvis tilnærming:

 
 Trinn 1 (0-2 mnd): Informasjon, egenhandtering og Øvelser

Hvordan diagnostiseres Vondt i Hoften? - Komplett guide?

Gjor-det-selv tester: Finn ut mer for du kommer

 

 For du bestiller time, kan du prøve disse enkle testene hjemme. De gir ofte en god pekepinn på hva som er galt - og gjør at jeg kommer raskere til bunns i problemet.

 
 
 1
 Sokke-testen (sjekker hofteleddet)

 

 
 Slik gjør du: Sitt på en stol. Prov å ta på deg sokker på den vonde siden uten å bøye ryggen mye - ved å trekke foten opp mot deg og rotere hoften utover.

 Resultat: Er det vanskelig eller gjør vondt dypt i lysken? Studier viser at dette er mye vanligere ved hofteartrose enn ved seneplager på utsiden. Det tyder på stivhet i selve hofteleddet.

 

 

 
 
 2
 Ett-bens-testen (sjekker setesenene)

 

 
 Slik gjør du: Stå på det vonde benet i 30 sekunder. Hold deg lett i veggen for balanse om nødvendig.

 Resultat: Hvis dette reproduserer den kjente smerten på utsiden av hoften, tyder det sterkt på GTPS (gluteal tendinopati). En fersk meta-analyse viste at denne testen har 94% sensitivitet og 99% spesifisitet for seneproblemer på utsiden av hoften.

 

 

 
 
 3
 Peke-testen (sjekker SI-ledd vs. hofte)

 

 
 Slik gjør du: Hvor sitter smerten? Prov å peke på det vondeste punktet med en finger.

 Resultat: Peker du rett på "smilehullet" eller gropen ved korsryggen? Da kommer smerten sannsynligvis fra SI-leddet (bekkenleddet), ikke hoften. Peker du derimot på lysken (ofte formet som en C med handen), er det oftere selve hofteleddet.

Patient asks: "What's the difference between herniation, disc herniation and sciatica?"

Herniation and disc herniation are the same thing - bulging of disc material. Sciatica is a symptom (radiating pain down the leg) that can be caused by herniation, but also other conditions like spinal stenosis or piriformis syndrome.

Describe treatment options for Dizziness - Complete Guide.

Prevention and Self-Treatment

 

 
 Measures You Can Do Yourself

 
 Move: The myth of bed rest for dizziness has been debunked. Adapted movement
 stimulates the balance system and helps the brain recalibrate.

 Vitamin D: Several meta-analyses show a connection between low vitamin D levels and
 BPPV. Supplementation may reduce relapse risk (Yang, J Neurol, 2020).

 Hydration: Drink sufficient fluids. Dehydration can worsen dizziness symptoms.

 Ergonomics: Screen at eye level, avoid forward-leaning head posture, take breaks
 every 30 minutes.

 Stress management: Stress worsens many forms of dizziness. Simple breathing
 exercises can calm an overactive nervous system.

 Secure your home: Remove loose rugs, ensure good lighting, use support handles in
 the bathroom.

Describe Myth 7: "It's all in your head" in the context of Dizziness: Myths Debunked and Real Help Available.

Myth 7: "It's all in your head"

 Fact: Dizziness is a real medical condition with concrete physical causes. That many also develop anxiety in connection with dizziness is understandable - the fear that symptoms will recur can be very burdensome.

 But anxiety resulting from dizziness is not the same as dizziness being "all in your head." A thorough examination will reveal whether there are underlying vestibular or musculoskeletal causes.

Describe treatment options for Dizziness - Causes, Symptoms and Effective Treatment.

Treatment Options

 

 
 BPPV

 Repositioning maneuvers (Epley/Semont) have an 80-90% success rate. Many experience significant improvement after 1-3 treatments.

 

 
 Neck-Related Dizziness

 Manual treatment, joint corrections and specific exercises. Typically 4-8 treatments over a few weeks.

 

 
 Vestibular Neuritis

 Vestibular rehabilitation and compensation training. 4-12 week program for more complex conditions.

 

 
 Meniere's Disease

 Lifestyle changes, medications and specialist follow-up.

 

 Vestibular Rehabilitation

 Vestibular rehabilitation is specialized physical therapy for the balance system with documented effect:

 
 Gaze stabilization - Exercises to maintain focus during head movements

 Balance exercises - Progressive training on challenging surfaces

 Habituation - Exposure to movements that trigger symptoms

 

 
 Most people with dizziness improve significantly with proper treatment. The key is finding the right diagnosis first.

Describe treatment options for POTS and Orthostatic Dizziness.

Treatment

 

 There is no cure for POTS, but most people experience significant improvement with the right treatment. Non-pharmacological measures are first-line treatment.

 Non-Pharmacological Treatment

 
 Fluids and salt: Drink 2-3 liters of water daily, start the day with 500 ml water BEFORE getting up. For POTS (without high blood pressure), increased salt intake is often recommended (6-10 grams daily). Always consult a doctor

 Compression: Class 2 compression stockings, best effect with stockings that go to the waist

 Diet: Eat small, frequent meals. Avoid large carbohydrate-rich meals

 

 
 The Levine Protocol: Exercise as Medicine

 Exercise is the well-documented treatment for POTS, but must be done correctly:

 
 Phase 1 (month 1-2): Horizontal exercise: rowing machine, recumbent bike, swimming

 Phase 2: Gradual introduction of upright exercise

 Phase 3: Maintenance with combined training

 
 

 
 Results from Research

 In Fu and Levine's study from 2011, 3 months of training showed that 53% of participants no longer met POTS criteria. Exercise was more effective than beta-blockers for reducing pulse and improving quality of life.

 

 What Can the Chiropractor Do?

 POTS is primarily a medical condition that requires evaluation by a doctor. But the chiropractor can play a role in several areas:

 
 Diagnostic contribution: I can perform active standing tests and identify if your dizziness may be due to POTS - rather than problems in the balance organ. If s...

Differensialdiagnoser ved lateral hoftesmerte:

1. Gluteal tendinopati / Trokanterittt bursitt (mest sannsynlig)
   - Typisk: Smerte over trochanter major, verst sideleie, trapper, gange
   - Tester: Palpasjon trochanter, FABER, resisted hip abduction
   - Behandling: Eksentrisk styrking, shockwave, unngå sideleie

2. IT-bånd syndrom
   - Smerte lateralt, kan stråle nedover
   - Forverres ved repetitiv fleksjon/ekstensjon
   - Ober's test positiv

3. Referert smerte fra lumbal columna (L4-L5)
   - Kan gi lateral hoftesmerte
   - Sjekk lumbal ROM, SLR, nevrologisk

4. Hofteleddsartrose
   - Vanligvis lyskesmerte, men kan gi lateral smerte
   - Redusert IR, FABER positiv

5. Meralgia paraesthetica (n. cutaneus femoris lateralis)
   - Brennende/prikking anterolateralt lår
   - Sensorisk, ikke motorisk

Anbefalt undersøkelsesstrategi:
- Palpasjon trochanter major og gluteal sener
- FABER, FADIR for hofteledd
- Lumbal screening for referert smerte
- Resisted hip abduction i sideleie
- Trendelenburg test

Describe Repetitive work in the context of Carpal Tunnel Syndrome: Complete Guide.

Repetitive work

 Office work, cashier work, production work - anything with repeated hand movements over time. See also
 mouse arm.
 

 

 Important risk factors

 
 Gender: Women are affected 3 times more often than men

 Pregnancy: Common in the last trimester (fluid retention)

 Diabetes: Increased risk of nerve disease in general

 Obesity: BMI over 30 significantly increases risk

 Arthritis: Inflammation can affect the tendon sheaths

 Hereditary: Tends to run in families

 
 

 
 
 3
 Symptoms

 

 The symptoms of carpal tunnel syndrome are often characteristic:

 
 Typical symptoms

 
 Tingling and numbness in thumb, index finger, middle finger and half of ring finger
 

 Night symptoms - waking up with "sleeping" hand

 Pain that can radiate up into the forearm

 Weakness - dropping things, problems with buttons

 "Electric shocks" in the fingers

 
 

 Why is it worst at night?

 Most people sleep with bent wrists, either under the head or curled toward the chest. When the wrist is
 bent, pressure in the carpal tunnel increases significantly - up to 10 times normal. This
 compresses the nerve and causes symptoms.

 
 Symptoms that worsen over time

 Without treatment, carpal tunnel syndrome can lead to:

 
 Constant numbness (not just at night)

 Muscle wasting at thumb base (thenar atrophy)

 Permanent nerve damage

 
 The earlier treatment starts, the better the prognosis.

 

 Where are your symptoms?

 
 
 
 Condition
 Fingers affected
 
 
 
 
 Carpal tunnel syndrome
 Thumb, index, middle, half ring finger
 
 
 Cubital tunnel syndrome
 Little finger, half ring finger
 
 
 Cervical radiculopathy
 Varies with nerve root, often entire arm
 
 
 
 

 
 
 4
 Diagnosis

 

 Diagnosis is primarily based on medical history and clinical examination. Provocation tests can confirm
 suspicion:

 
 Phalen's test

 Hold wrists flexed for 60 seconds. Positive test: symptoms in the median nerve area are triggered.

Describe symptoms - how to tell them apart? for Rib Dislocation vs. Rib Fracture.

Symptoms - How to Tell Them Apart?

 Both conditions cause pain that worsens with breathing and movement. But there are some important
 differences
 Characteristic 
 Rib Fracture 
 Rib Dislocation 

 Trauma history 
 Clear - you remember exactly when/how 
 Often vague or none 

 Pain onset 
 Immediately after trauma 
 Gradual or sudden without trauma 

 With pressure 
 Extreme tenderness, possible crepitation 
 Moderate tenderness, trigger points 

 Swelling/bruising 
 Often visible after 1-2 weeks 
 None or minimal 

 Breathing 
 Shallow, very limited 
 Can take deep breaths (but it hurts) 

 Pain intensity 
 Very intense 
 Moderate to strong 

 The Main Rule: With rib fractures, the patient remembers exactly when and how the pain
 started - there was trauma. With rib dislocation, the history is often more vague: "I just woke up with
 it" or "It came after I had been sitting for a long time."

Hvor vanlige er fotplager?

Describe PPPD: When Dizziness Becomes Chronic for Dizzy from Stress and Anxiety - When Brain and Balance Are Connected.

PPPD: When Dizziness Becomes Chronic

 

 Persistent Postural-Perceptual Dizziness (PPPD) is the most common form of chronic functional dizziness. The condition affects 15-23% of patients at specialist clinics.

 
 Who Gets PPPD?

 
 Women are affected four times more often than men

 Typical age of onset: 30-50 years

 Often triggered by a vestibular event, migraine, panic attack, or concussion

 
 

 
 Diagnostic Criteria (Barany Society 2017)

 All five criteria must be met:

 
 Duration: Dizziness, unsteadiness, or non-rotational vertigo most days for at least 3 months

 Aggravating factors: Symptoms worsen with upright posture, movement, and visually complex environments

 Triggering event: Started after vestibular disease, migraine, panic attack, or concussion

 Symptoms cause significant discomfort or functional impairment

 Not better explained by another condition

You are a diagnosis code specialist for chiropractic in Norway. You help select the correct ICPC-2 codes based on clinical findings and symptoms. Always provide the code first, then a brief explanation.
Acute vs chronic low back pain — difference in coding?

Acute vs chronic low back:

- Acute (<6 weeks): L03 — Low back symptom
- Subacute (6-12 weeks): L03 or L84 depending on workup
- Chronic (>12 weeks): L84 — Back syndrome without radiation

Transition from L03 → L84 when:
- Pain persists >12 weeks
- Clinical syndrome identified
- Imaging shows pathology

Error: Using L03 for chronic pain lasting 2 years without reassessment.

Forklar Prepatellar Bursitt for en pasient.

Har du fatt en hevelse foran kneskailen som er om og varm å ta på? Dette kan være prepatellar bursitt - en vanlig tilstand som ofte kalles "kneskalbetennelse" eller "housemaid's knee" på engelsk. Knesmerter kan ha mange årsaker, og prepatellar bursitt er en av de lettere gjenkjennelige.

 Tilstanden oppstår når slimposen foran kneskailen blir irritert og betent, vanligvis på grunn av gjentatt press eller friksjon. Det er en yrkesrelatert plage hos flisleggere, snekkere, gartnere og andre som arbeider mye på knarne.

 De fleste tilfeller responderer godt på konservativ behandling, men det er viktig å utelukke infeksjon som krever rask behandling.

Treatment Course and Prognosis

 

 Typical treatment course is 6-12 treatments over 4-8 weeks.

 
 Important About Timing

 Improvement in tinnitus often comes 2-3 weeks after jaw pain begins to subside. Full effect can take 3-6 months. Ear fullness is often the symptom that responds fastest.

 

 For properly selected patients - those with clear connection between jaw and ear symptoms - studies show that 44-83% achieve significant improvement in tinnitus, and about half experience complete or near-complete improvement.

 It is Important to be Realistic

 
 Not everyone responds equally well - some experience only partial improvement

 Relapses are common in TMD, especially with persistent stress or teeth clenching

 Treatment takes time - expect 3-6 months for optimal effect

 Many need maintenance treatment or periodic follow-up

Describe Which nerves are affected - and what characterizes each? for Cervical Disc Herniation and Pinched Nerve in the Neck.

Which nerves are affected - and what characterizes each?

 

 The neck has seven cervical vertebrae, and the nerves exiting between them are named after the vertebra
 above. Note: Only 62.6% of patients have standard dermatome patterns, and 67.3% show typical myotome
 patterns (Neurospine 2022). About one-third have atypical symptoms.

 
 C7 radiculopathy (most common - 60-70% of cases)

 
 Disc level: C6-C7

 Sensory: Tingling, numbness in the middle
 finger (finger 3). May also be felt on the back of the forearm.

 Muscle weakness: Triceps (elbow extension), wrist flexors and finger extensors.
 

 Reflex change: Reduced triceps reflex.

 
 

 
 C6 radiculopathy (second most common - 20-25%)

 
 Disc level: C5-C6

 Sensory: Tingling or numbness in thumb and index finger (fingers 1 and 2).

 Muscle weakness: Biceps and wrist extensors.

 Reflex change: Reduced biceps reflex and/or brachioradialis reflex.

 
 NOTE: C6 radiculopathy
 shows the most variation - only 47.6% present with typical pattern.

 

 
 C5 radiculopathy (~5% of cases)

 
 Disc level: C4-C5

 Sensory: Pain and tingling in the shoulder area and outer upper arm.

 Muscle weakness: Deltoid (shoulder abduction) and biceps.

 Reflex change: Reduced biceps reflex.

 
 

 
 C8 radiculopathy (~5% of cases)

 
 Disc level: C7-T1

 Sensory: Numbness in ring and little finger (fingers 4 and 5) plus inner forearm.
 

 Muscle weakness: Small muscles of the hand and finger flexors. Causes problems
 with fine motor skills...

Describe Pregnancy and Lower Back Pain for Lower Back Pain – Complete Guide.

Pregnancy and Lower Back Pain

 

 Go to full article on pregnancy and back pain ?

 Approximately 50% of pregnant women experience lower back pain (Wu et al., European Spine Journal 2004). For some, the problems start early; for others, not until the last trimester.

 
 Why Do Pregnant Women Get Back Pain?

 Hormonal changes:

 
 Relaxin loosens ligaments and joints å provides less stability

 Muscles have to work harder to compensate

 
 Mechanical changes:

 
 Center of gravity shifts forward

 Increased curve in the lower back (hyperlordosis)

 Weight gain of 10–15 kg

 
 

 Types of Pain During Pregnancy

 
 Lumbar pain: Central in the lower back, similar to regular lower back pain

 Pelvic pain: Four times more common. Over the SI joints and/or pubic symphysis.

 Symphysis dysfunction: Pronounced pain over the pubic symphysis, difficulty walking

 

 
 Treatment During Pregnancy

 Chiropractic treatment is safe during pregnancy:

 
 Adapted joint treatment

 Soft tissue therapy

 Pelvic belts for pelvic pain

 Exercises and ergonomic advice

Beskriv diagnostikk for Rotator Cuff — Komplett Guide til Rotatorkuffen.

Diagnostikk

 En grundig klinisk undersokelse er fundamentet for diagnosen. Bildediagnostikk er ofte unodvendig for a starte behandling.

 Kliniske tester

 Jobe's test (Empty Can)

 Tester supraspinatus. Armen loftes med tommelen ned. Smerte eller svakhet er positivt funn. Sensitivitet ca. 70-80%.

 Utadrotasjon med motstand

 Tester infraspinatus og teres minor. Albuen i 90 grader, roter utover mot motstand. Svakhet tyder pa bakre rotatorcuff-affeksjon.

 Lift-off test / Bear-hug test

 Tester subscapularis. Handen plasseres bak ryggen (lift-off) eller pa motsatt skulder (bear-hug). Svakhet tyder pa subscapularis-affeksjon.

 Drop arm test

 Armen holdes passivt loftet ut til siden. Hvis pasienten ikke klarer a senke armen kontrollert, tyder det pa fulltykkelse-ruptur. Hoy spesifisitet.

 Bildediagnostikk

 Ultralyd vs. MR

 Ultralyd er et godt forstvalg for a vurdere rotatorkuffen. Det er billig, tilgjengelig, og har sammenlignbar noyaktighet med MR for a pavis rupturer. Ulempen er at kvaliteten avhenger av undersokeren.

 MR gir mer detaljert informasjon om rupturens storrelse, muskelkvalitet (fettinfiltrasjon) og andre strukturer. MR er mest aktuelt nar kirurgi vurderes.

 Nar er bildediagnostikk aktuelt?

 Bildediagnostikk vurderes ved: akutt traume med svakhet, mistanke om stor ruptur, manglende bedring etter 6-12 uker med trening, eller nar kirurgi vurderes. For de fleste er klinisk undersokelse tilstrekkelig for a starte behandling.

Hvordan diagnostiseres Spinal Stenose - Tranghet i Ryggen?

Diagnostikk

 

 Klinisk undersøkelse

 Som kiropraktor gjør jeg en grundig undersøkelse som inkluderer vurdering av gangmønster og holdning, testing av reflekser, kraft og fålsomhet i beina, og provokasjon av symptomer ved ulike stillinger.

 Bildediagnostikk - et viktig forbehold

 MR er førstevalgundersøkelse når bildediagnostikk er indisert. Men her kommer et svært viktig poeng: Det er ofte dårlig sammenheng mellom MR-funn og symptomer.

 
 MR-funn hos symptomfrie

 Studier viser at 21% av symptomfrie personer over 60 Ør har stenose på MR, og at 65% av friske frivillige fikk stenosediagnose av radiologer. Dette betyr at MR-bilder aldri bør styre behandlingen alene.

 

 Bildediagnostikk er mest aktuelt ved:

 
 Mistanke om alvorlig patologi (røde flagg)

 Vedvarende symptomer etter 6-8 ukers konservativ behandling

 Ved vurdering av kirurgi

Beskriv symptomer for Meralgia Paresthetica.

Symptomer

 Typiske symptomer

 Brennende smerte på utsiden av læret

 Nummenhet - nedsatt følelse i huden

 Prikking eller stikking - "maur som kryper"

 Hyperestesi - overfølsomhet, vondt ved lett berøring

 Symptomer i et avgrenset område - ca. 15x20 cm på læret

 Viktige kjennetegn

 Kun følelsessymptomer - aldri muskelsvakhet

 Ensidig - rammer vanligvis bare ett lær (hos 80%)

 Forverres ved standing/gang - bedres ved å sitte

 Ingen rygg- eller lyskesmerter 

 Symptomene forverres ved
 Lang standing

 Lengre gange

 Hofteekstensjon (strekke hoften bakover)

 Stramme bukser eller belte

 Ligge på magen

 Symptomene bedres ved
 Sitte - spesielt med bøyd hofte

 Løse klær

 Bøye hoften fremover

 Hvordan skille fra andre tilstander?

 Meralgia paresthetica gir ingen svakhet i benet. Hvis du har svakhet i lar eller hofte, kommer symptomene sannsynligvis fra ryggen eller en annen nerve. Isjias gir symptomer på baksiden av benet, ikke fremsiden. Smerter på utsiden av hoften kan også skyldes GTPS/gluteal tendinopati , mens smerter dypt i setet kan tyde på piriformis syndrom .

Describe Visually Triggered Dizziness (40%) in the context of Vestibular Migraine: When Dizziness Takes Over Your Life.

Visually Triggered Dizziness (40%)

 Worsens in busy visual environments (shopping centers, escalators). Scrolling on screens triggers symptoms.

 

 Accompanying Symptoms:

 
 Nausea (72% of patients)

 Light and sound sensitivity

 Pressure in head or ears

 Tinnitus - often high-frequency

 Neck pain and stiffness - very common! See also cervicogenic dizziness

 
 

 
 
 4
 Diagnosis

 

 Barany Society/IHS Diagnostic Criteria:

 For the diagnosis "Definite Vestibular Migraine" the following must be met:

 
 At least 5 episodes with vestibular symptoms of moderate to severe intensity

 Duration from 5 minutes to 72 hours

 Current or past history of migraine (with or without aura)

 At least 50% of attacks must have at least one migraine feature: headache, light/sound sensitivity, or visual aura

 Symptoms cannot be better explained by another diagnosis

 

 Differential Diagnosis:

 
 
 
 Condition
 Duration
 Distinctive Features
 
 
 
 
 Vestibular Migraine
 Minutes to hours
 Migraine features, gradual onset
 
 
 BPPV (Crystal Disease)
 Seconds
 Sudden onset, specific head position
 
 
 Meniere's Disease
 Hours
 Progressive hearing loss, unilateral fullness
 
 
 Vestibular Neuritis
 Days
 Single episode, gradual improvement
 
 
 

 
 Red Flags - See a Doctor or Emergency Room for:

 
 Sudden, intense headache ("the worst headache of my life")

 Headache with fever and neck stiffness

 Unilateral hearing loss or tinnitus

 Double vision or vision loss

 Weakness or numbness in face, arm or leg

 Speech or language difficulties

 Fainting in connection with dizziness

Causes of Dizziness - From Most to Least Common

 

 Here are the main causes, sorted by how often they occur:

 
 
 BPPV (Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo)

 17-42% of cases
 

 Go to full article on BPPV →

 BPPV is the most common cause of dizziness investigated in clinics (Bosner, BMC Fam Pract, 2018). The
 condition occurs when small calcium crystals detach from their place in the balance organ and end up in
 the semicircular canals.

 Characteristics:

 
 Short, intense spinning attacks (10-60 seconds)

 Triggered by specific head movements - turning in bed, looking up, bending down

 Nausea during attacks

 Symptom-free between attacks

 
 

 
 
 Vestibular Migraine

 approx. 1-3% of population
 

 Go to full article on
 vestibular migraine →

 Lifetime prevalence around 1%, but newer American data suggests up to 2.7% (Formeister, Otol Neurotol,
 2018). The Barany Society has identified this as "by far the most common cause" of combined neck pain
 and vestibular symptoms. Can occur with or without headache.

 

 
 
 Vestibular Neuritis

 3-10% in dizziness clinics
 

 Go to full article on
 vestibular neuritis →

 Annual incidence of 3.5-7 per 100,000 (Iwasaki, Auris Nasus Larynx, 2024). Accounts for 3-10% of
 diagnoses in specialised dizziness clinics. Viral inflammation of the balance nerve causing sudden,
 intense dizziness over several days. Hearing is not affected. 10-15% develop BPPV afterwards.

Identify red flags for Red Flags for Neck Pain - When to See a Doctor.

The Chiropractor's Role with Red Flags

 

 When arterial dissection or myelopathy is suspected, the chiropractor's most important task is early
 recognition and rapid referral. I do not treat patients where there is suspicion of these conditions.

 At all new patient encounters, I conduct a thorough medical history and neurological screening. If you
 have symptoms as described above, I will assess whether you need acute medical evaluation - either via
 emergency room, emergency services, or direct referral to imaging and specialist.

 
 Measures that may be safe while awaiting specialist evaluation

 
 Soft tissue mobilization of thoracic region (avoiding deep pressure on neck)

 Patient education on posture and activity modification

 Gentle isometric neck exercises

 
 

 
 Contraindicated Measures

Beskriv Smale BH-stropper i kontekst av BH-stropp-syndrom og skuldersmerter.

Smale BH-stropper

 Forskning fra University of Wollongong (2015) viser at brede stropper (4,5 cm) reduserer topptrykket med ca. 35% sammenlignet med standard 2,5 cm stropper.

 

 Andre faktorer

 
 Lang daglig brukstid: De fleste kvinner bruker BH 12-14 timer daglig. Trykk på bare 9 kPa over 2 timer kan gi hud- og muskelskade.

 Dårlig holdning: Avrundede skuldre Øker belastningen på stroppene og kan forsterke kompresjonen.

 Racerback-BHer: Samler stroppene nårmere nakken og kan Øke trykket på sensitive områder.

 
 

 
 
 
 3
 Symptomer

 

 Det typiske symptombildet har et karakteristisk mønster:

 
 Typiske symptomer

 
 Skulder- og nakkesmerter - ofte på begge sider, men kan våre verre på en side

 Smertene er minimale om morgenen og blir gradvis verre utover dagen

 Lindring når BH-en fjernes - dette er et viktig diagnostisk tegn

 Nummenhet eller prikking ned i armen (på grunn av nervekompresjon)

 Synlige furer eller merker der stroppene sitter

 Hodepine - ofte fra bakhodet og oppover

 Tretthet i skuldrene, spesielt ved langvarig stående eller børing av vesker

Describe What is BPPV (Crystal Disease)? for Dizzy When Lying Down? What You Need to Know About BPPV.

What is BPPV (Crystal Disease)?

 

 The condition is benign - it is not caused by serious illness - but can be very bothersome and significantly affect daily life.

 
 How common is it?

 BPPV affects around 2.4% of the population during their lifetime. In Norway, this corresponds to approximately 80,000 new cases each year. The condition is most common in people over 50 years old, and women are affected twice as often as men.

 By age 80, up to 10% of the population has experienced at least one episode. A Norwegian registry study showed that dizziness accounts for nearly 1% of all long-term sick leave.

Årsaker

 Ulnarnerven er sårbar ved albuen av flere grunner
 Bøyd albue Vanligst 

 Når albuen bøyes, strekkes og komprimeres ulnarnerven. Langvarig albuebøy (sove, telefon, tastatur) er hovedårsaken.

 Lene på albuen

 å lene albuen på armlene, bord eller bildørarmen over tid gir direkte trykk på nerven.

 Anatomiske faktorer

 Noen har naturlig trang kubitaltunnel eller nerven som "hopper" ut av spøret ved albuebøy.

 Tidligere skader

 Albuebrudd, luksasjon eller artrose kan trange tunnelen og irritere nerven.

 Viktige risikofaktorer

 Kontorarbeid: Langvarig tastaturbruk med bøyde albuer (se også musearm )

 Sovevaner: Sove med armene under hodet/puten

 Telefonbruk: Langvarige samtaler med bøyd albue

 Leddgikt: Kan gi hevelse rundt nerven

 Diabetes: Øker risikoen for nerveplager generelt

Describe How the Balance System Gets Involved for The Connection Between Jaw, Neck and Dizziness.

How the Balance System Gets Involved

 

 The balance system (the vestibular system) also has direct connections to the upper neck. The same cervical vertebrae that participate in the trigeminocervical complex send proprioceptive signals (position sense) directly to the balance nuclei in the brainstem.

 The suboccipital muscles (the small muscles at the top of the neck) have the highest concentration of position sense cells in the entire body - 242 muscle spindles per gram compared to only 2.2 per gram in the trapezius.

 When these muscles are tense or dysfunctional, signals to the brain can become disturbed. The result is a sensory mismatch - the brain receives conflicting information from eyes, ears, and neck, and this is experienced as dizziness.

Provide a structured clinical overview of Plantar Fasciopathy.

What is Plantar Fasciopathy?: The suffix -itis means inflammation, but histological studies actually show absence of
 inflammatory cells in the tissue. What happens is degenerative changes: breakdown of collagen
 fibers, thickening of the fascia, and reduced blood supply. Therefore, many professionals now use the term
 plantar fasciopathy - a more precise description of what is actually happening in the tissue (Riel et al.,
 BJSM 2017).

Symptoms: The most characteristic symptom is intense heel pain with the first steps in the morning 
 - so-called start-up pain. The pain occurs because the plantar fascia contracts during the night while the
 foot rests, and the sudden loading when standing up causes stretching pain.

Causes and Risk Factors: Research has identified several risk factors, ranked by how strongly they affect the chance of developing
 the condition
The Heel Spur Myth: Fact: This is not correct. Studies show
Treatment: Conservative treatment is the first choice, and over 80-90% respond well to this
 (StatPearls 2024). Only 5-10% eventually need surgical treatment.

Prognosis and Expected Course: Plantar fasciopathy generally has a good prognosis. 80-90% improve significantly with
 conservative treatment within 12 months.

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for FAI - Hip Impingement.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 What is the difference between cam and pincer?

 Cam FAI is caused by a bump on the femoral head impinging
 against the socket. Pincer FAI is caused by the socket extending too far out. Cam is
 most common in men, pincer in women. most have a combination (mixed type).

 

 
 Does FAI need surgery?

 No, most people with FAI do not need surgery. The UK FASHIoN
 study showed that physical therapy was almost as effective as surgery after 12
 months. Surgery is considered only after 3-6 months without sufficient improvement
 from conservative treatment.

 

 
 Can I continue to exercise?

 Yes, but with modifications. Avoid exercises that cause pain,
 especially deep squats and extreme hip positions. Many activities can continue with
 modifications. Hip strength training is actually important for improvement.

 

 
 Will FAI lead to osteoarthritis?

 FAI is a risk factor for hip
 osteoarthritis, but most do not develop osteoarthritis. Good muscle strength
 and control can reduce risk. It is unclear if treatment prevents osteoarthritis
 long-term.

 

 
 Why did I get FAI?

 FAI morphology typically develops in adolescence during bone
 growth. Genetics play a role, and intensive sports in adolescence (especially
 soccer, hockey, dance) can affect hip shape. It's not something you "did wrong".

Describe treatment options for Stress Neck and Trigger Points.

Treatment

 

 
 What can the chiropractor do?

 A network meta-analysis from 2024 shows that manual therapy provides short-term improvement in pain, pressure sensitivity and function for trigger points. Treatment includes:

 
 Ischemic compression: Sustained pressure on the trigger point

 Dry needling: Thin needles in the trigger point

 Mobilization: Soft tissue treatment and joint movement

 Exercise-based rehabilitation: The most important thing for lasting improvement

 
 

 
 What can you do yourself?

 
 Strength training: Neck/shoulder strength exercises 2-3 times per week have moderate to good evidence for pain relief

 Stretching: Hold each stretch for 30 seconds - this is optimal duration according to research

 Breathing techniques: Diaphragmatic breathing (belly breathing) activates the vagus nerve which dampens the stress response

 Ergonomics: Screen at eye level, forearms supported, regular breaks

 
 

 
 For lasting improvement, you should combine treatment with strength training and stress management. Short-term effects of treatment are well documented.

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Headache in Back of Head.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 Can stress cause headache in the back of the head?

 Yes, stress is one of the most important triggers for tension headache. Stress often leads to increased tension in neck and shoulder muscles, which in turn can cause pain in the back of the head.

 

 
 When should I see a chiropractor for headache?

 You can see a chiropractor for headache that you suspect comes from the neck or muscles - that is, when the pain worsens with neck movements, sedentary work, or muscle tension. For sudden, severe headache or neurological symptoms, you should contact a doctor first.

 

 
 How long does it take for treatment to help?

 Most people notice some improvement within the first 2-4 weeks. For cervicogenic headache, research shows that optimal effect is achieved after 12-18 treatments over 3-6 months. The effect is best maintained with home exercises.

 

 
 Is headache in the back of the head dangerous?

 The vast majority of cases are due to benign causes such as muscle tension or neck problems. Sudden, intense headache, headache with fever and neck stiffness, or new-onset headache in people over 50 should always be evaluated by a doctor.

 

 
 Does exercise help headache in the back of the head?

 Yes, specific exercises for neck muscles have good documentation. Chin tucks and deep neck flexor training can reduce both the frequency and intensity of headache over time.

 

 
 Do I need an MRI or X-ray?

 Rarely for typical headache. Imaging is prim...

Symptomer ved C6-C7 prolaps

 

 Symptomene ved C6-C7 prolaps følger C7-nervens forsyningsområde og er ofte mer distinkte enn ved andre nivåer.

 
 Typiske C7-symptomer

 
 Smerte: Strøler fra nakke og skulder, ned baksiden av overarmen til langfingeren

 Nummenhet/prikking: Langfingeren er mest rammet, kan inkludere deler av peke- og ringfinger

 Svakhet: Triceps (vansker med å strekke albuen mot motstand), fingerfleksjon

 Refleksendring: Redusert eller fravårende tricepsrefleks

 
 

 Det klassiske smerteprofilen

 C7-radikulopati har et karakteristisk mønster:

 
 Smertens forløp

 
 Starter ofte med nakkestivhet eller hodepine

 Utvikler seg til skuldersmerte over dager til uker

 Strøler gradvis nedover armen til handen

 Nummenhet i fingre kommer gjerne sist

 
 

 Forverrende og lindrende faktorer

 
 Forverres typisk av:

 
 Å vri hodet mot den affiserte siden

 Bakover-bøyning av nakken (ekstensjon)

 Hosting, nysing eller pressing

 Langvarig stillesitting med fremskutt hode

 
 

 
 Lindres typisk av:

 
 Å legge handen på hodet (Bakody's tegn)

 Lett nakkebøyning fremover

 Å støtte armen på en pute

Describe the 12 most common types of dizziness for Types of Dizziness: How to Tell the Difference Between Different Forms.

The 12 Most Common Types of Dizziness

 Peripheral Causes (from the balance organ)

 1. BPPV (Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo) - Most Common

 Prevalence: 17-42% of all dizziness cases

 Small calcium crystals detach from their place in the balance organ and end up in the semicircular canals, where they disturb balance registration.

 Brief episodes (10-60 seconds) with head movements

 Triggered by turning in bed, looking up, or bending down

 Symptom-free between episodes

 Treatment: The Epley maneuver has an 80-90% success rate.

 Read more about BPPV → 

 2. Vestibular Migraine

 Prevalence: 1-3% of the population

 Dizziness as part of migraine episodes - can occur with or without headache. The Barany Society calls this "by far the most common cause" of combined neck pain and vestibular symptoms.

 Episodes from minutes to days

 Often light and sound sensitivity

 Migraine history in patient or family

 Read more about vestibular migraine → 

 3. Meniere's Disease

 Prevalence: About 10 times rarer than BPPV

 Chronic condition with increased fluid pressure in the inner ear. Causes classic episodes with four main symptoms.

 Severe vertigo (20 minutes to several hours)

 Fluctuating hearing loss (low-frequency tones first)

 Tinnitus (ear ringing)

 Pressure sensation in the affected ear

 Read more about Meniere's disease → 

 4. Mal de Debarquement (MdDS)

 Persistent rocking or swaying sensation - typically after a boat trip, flight, or car ride. Can last months or years.

 Paradoxically: Better during movement, worse at rest

 Most commonly affects women in their 40s-50s

 Read more about MdDS → 

 5. Cervicogenic Dizziness

 Dizziness related to neck problems. The diagnosis is controversial - the Barany Society refrains from proposing diagnostic criteria due to lack of documentation.

Diagnostikk

 

 TMD diagnostiseres primert gjennom klinisk undersøkelse. Kiropraktoren vil underske kjeveleddet, tyggemusklene, nakken og hodets bevegelse. Gapeevne males, og vi lytter etter lyder fra leddet.

 Bildediagnostikk (MR/røntgen) er sjelden nødvendig ved typiske TMD-symptomer. Studier viser at bildefunn ofte ikke korrelerer med symptomer - mange uten plager har "unormale" funn på MR, og mange med plager har normale bilder. Klinisk undersøkelse er derfor viktigere enn bilder i de fleste tilfeller.

 
 Når er bilder aktuelle?

 Bilder kan vare aktuelle ved mistanke om strukturelle forandringer, etter traume, eller hvis konservativ behandling ikke gir effekt over tid.

Prognose

 De første tre månedene er kritiske. De fleste som skal bli friske, bedres i denne perioden - deretter flater bedringskurven ut.

 50% 
 bedres innen 3-6 mnd 

 64%

 vedvarende symptomer ved 1 år 

 Viktig å vite

Beskriv Ofte stilte spørsmål for Brystryggsmerter.

Ofte stilte spørsmål

 

 
 Hva er de vanligste Årsakene til brystryggsmerter?

 De vanligste Årsakene er muskulære spenninger (særlig mellom skulderbladene), leddysfunksjon i brystvirvlene, ribbeinslasning, kostokondritt, og
 holdningsrelaterte problemer som krum rygg. I sjeldne tilfeller kan det
 skyldes mer alvorlige tilstander som thorakalt prolaps som krever
 utredning.

 

 
 Kan brystryggsmerter komme fra hjertet?

 Ja, brystsmerter kan i noen tilfeller våre hjerterelatert, særlig hos kvinner der
 symptomene ofte er atypiske. Ved plutselig smerte kombinert med pustevansker, kvalme, utstråling til arm
 eller kaldsvette bør du søke akutt hjelp.

 

 
 Kan kiropraktor hjelpe mot brystryggsmerter?

 Ja, kiropraktisk behandling har moderat til god evidens for thorakale plager.
 Manuell behandling kombinert med målrettede Øvelser gir ofte gode resultater. De fleste opplever bedring
 innen 4-6 uker.

 

 
 Når bør jeg oppsøke lege for brystryggsmerter?

 Søk lege ved: plutselig intens smerte, smerter som stråler til brystet eller
 armen, pustevansker, feber, uforklarlig vekttap, nattsmerter som vekker deg, eller smerter etter traume.
 Også ved symptomer som nummenhet eller svakhet i bena.

Patient asks: "Can forward head posture cause jaw problems?"

Yes. When the head pushes forward, the load on neck muscles increases by up to 60%. This postural change activates jaw muscles compensatorily and changes the jaw's resting position. Studies show that 60-66% of office workers have forward head posture.

Forklar prognose - hvordan går det? for Migrene: Alt du trenger å vite.

Prognose - hvordan går det?

 Migrene er en kronisk tilstand - målet er å redusere anfallsfrekvens og intensitet, ikke nødvendigvis å fjerne alle anfall. Data fra den amerikanske AMPP-studien (Lipton et al., 2007) viser at ved 1-Ørs oppfølging
 84% 
 har fortsatt migrene 

 10% 
 Oppnår full remisjon 

 3% 
 forverres til kronisk 

 Det er altså mulig å bli bedre - og kronisk migrene kan også reverseres. Studier viser at 26-27% av pasienter med kronisk migrene går tilbake til episodisk form innen 2 år (Manack et al., Neurology 2011).

 Faktorer som bedrer prognosen

 Lavere baseline-frekvens

 Fravar av medikamentoverforbruk

 Fravar av depresjon

 God søvnkvalitet

 Anfallshyppigheten tenderer til å avta med alderen. Fra 60-Ørsalder øker remisjonsratene merkbart, særlig hos menn.

 Medikamentoverforbrukshodepine 

 Regelmessig bruk av triptaner 10+ dager/måned eller vanlige smertestillende 15+ dager/måned over 3 måneder kan gi MOH (medikamentoverforbrukshodepine). MOH identifiseres hos opptil 78-80% av kronisk daglig cefalalgi-pasienter.

Describe causes - from most common to rarest for Dizzy When Lying Down? What You Need to Know About BPPV.

Causes - From Most Common to Rarest

 Possible causes

 Idiopathic (unknown cause): 50-70% of cases - the crystals dislodge without finding any specific reason

 Age-related: Risk increases significantly after age 50, likely due to natural wear and tear

 Migraine: Four times higher risk compared to people without migraine

 Head injury: Accounts for 7-17% of cases

 Vestibular neuritis: About 10% develop BPPV after this viral infection

 Osteoporosis and vitamin D deficiency: Increased risk, likely due to affected calcium metabolism

Describe the five diagnostic criteria (barany society, 2017) for Chronic Dizziness and PPPD.

The Five Diagnostic Criteria (Barany Society, 2017)

 1. Duration

 Dizziness, unsteadiness or non-rotational vertigo present most days for at least three months

 2. Aggravating Factors

 Symptoms worsen with upright posture, active or passive movement, and visually complex or moving stimuli

 3. Triggering Event

 The condition started after an acute vestibular disorder, other medical illness, or psychological stress

 4. Symptom Impact

 Symptoms cause significant distress or functional impairment

 5. No Better Explanation

 Symptoms cannot be better explained by another disease

Differential diagnoses for Thoracic Back Pain?

Scheuermann's Disease

 A developmental disorder causing increased kyphosis (rounding) in the thoracic spine, usually discovered in adolescence.

 Abnormal rounding of the upper back

 Stiffness and aching pain

 Wedged vertebrae visible on X-ray

 Can be treated conservatively in most cases

Thoracic Disc Herniation

 Rarer than in the neck and lower back, but can occur. Accounts for only 1-2% of all disc herniations.

 Often asymptomatic even when found on MRI

 Can cause radiation around the ribs

 Rarely requires surgery

Ankylosing Spondylitis

 Rheumatic disease causing inflammation and gradual stiffening of the spine.

 Morning stiffness over 30 minutes

 Improves with activity

 Often onset before age 40

 Requires referral to rheumatologist

Describe treatment options for Calcific Tendinitis: Everything You Need to Know.

Treatment

 

 Treatment of calcific tendinitis depends on symptom intensity and phase. Because the condition is
 self-limiting, the goal is to relieve symptoms while the body takes care of the calcium itself.

 Conservative treatment (first choice)

 
 What can the chiropractor/physiotherapist do?

 
 Manual therapy: Mobilization of shoulder and thoracic spine

 Soft tissue treatment: Work on tight muscles around the shoulder

 Exercise guidance: Tailored exercises to maintain mobility and strength

 Ergonomic advice: Adaptation of work tasks during acute phase. See ergonomics and shoulder problems

 
 

 Shockwave Therapy (ESWT)

 ESWT (Extracorporeal Shock Wave Therapy) has Level I evidence for treating calcific
 tendinitis. Shock waves are sent toward the calcium deposit to stimulate resorption and relieve pain.
 

 
 The KALK Study (BMJ 2023)

 A Norwegian study (the KALK study) compared ESWT with placebo. Interestingly, the study showed no
 significant difference between groups at 4 and 12 months. This may be because patients with shorter
 symptom duration were included - where the condition might have resolved anyway.

 Other studies with longer symptom duration have shown better effect of ESWT. The treatment may be
 most useful for patients with long-term symptoms that show no signs of spontaneous improvement.

 

 Other treatment options

 
 Ultrasound-guided barbotage (needling)

 A needle is inserted into the calcium deposit under ultrasound guidance. Calcium slur...

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Carpal Tunnel Syndrome: Complete Guide.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 Why do my hands go numb at night?

 When you sleep, the wrist is often bent, which significantly increases pressure in
 the carpal tunnel. This compresses the median nerve and causes tingling and numbness. A night splint
 that keeps the wrist in neutral position can help 50-70% of patients.

 

 
 Do I need surgery?

 Not necessarily. Many recover with conservative treatment such as night splint and
 manual therapy. AAOS 2024 recommends trying conservative treatment first. Surgery is considered for
 severe symptoms or no effect after 3-6 months.

 

 
 Can carpal tunnel syndrome go away on its own?

 Mild cases can improve spontaneously, especially if there's a temporary cause
 (like pregnancy). But without treatment, most cases worsen over time. The earlier you start treatment,
 the better the prognosis.

 

 
 Is it dangerous to wait with treatment?

 Long-term, untreated carpal tunnel syndrome can cause permanent nerve damage with
 constant numbness and muscle wasting. Early treatment prevents this.

 

 
 Can I continue working at a computer?

 Yes, but you should consider ergonomic adjustments. Keyboard height, mouse type,
 and frequent breaks are important. An ergonomic assessment can identify problems.

 

 
 What's the difference between carpal tunnel and cubital tunnel?

 Carpal tunnel syndrome affects the median nerve in the wrist and causes symptoms
 in thumb, index, middle and ring finger. Cubital tunnel
 syndrome affects the uln...

 Symptoms of AC joint osteoarthritis are often characteristic and localized:

 Typical Symptoms

How is Trigger Points in the Neck - Muscle Knots and Referred Pain diagnosed?

Diagnosis

 

 Diagnosis is made through clinical examination. An international Delphi study from 2018 with 60 experts
 from 12 countries concluded that the most important diagnostic criteria are: a taut band in the muscle, a
 hypersensitive point, and reproduction of referred pain with pressure (Fernandez-de-las-Penas & Dommerholt
 2018).

 
 Important to know

 There are no internationally validated diagnostic criteria for MPS. Inter-examiner reliability is only
 moderate. This means that two practitioners examining the same patient may find trigger points in
 slightly different locations. We therefore use the clinical examination as a starting point, but also
 emphasize your experience and response to treatment.

 

 Imaging

 MRI and X-ray are rarely necessary for trigger points. Images often show age-related changes (wear,
 degeneration) that don't explain your pain. Ultrasound can detect trigger points as darker areas with
 increased stiffness, but this is currently mostly used in research.
